"deu": "Trump-Anh\u00e4ngerin will Vorsitzenden des US-Repr\u00e4sentantenhauses st\u00fcrzen und scheitert", "fra": "\u00c9tats-Unis. Une \u00e9lue trumpiste d\u00e9clenche une proc\u00e9dure de destitution contre un chef du Congr\u00e8s"}, "summary": {"eng": "Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia moved on Wednesday to oust Speaker Mike Johnson from his post, teeing up a snap vote on whether to allow the Louisiana Republican to keep his gavel in a remarkable act of political retribution that she has been threatening for weeks.\n\nMs. Greene's move came roughly three weeks after Mr. Johnson pushed through a long-stalled $95 billion national security spending package to aid Israel, Ukraine and other American allies over the objections of Ms. Gre", "deu": "In den USA ist die gl\u00fchende Trump-Anh\u00e4ngerin Marjorie Taylor Greene mit einem Versuch gescheitert, den Vorsitzenden des Repr\u00e4sentantenhauses, Mike Johnson, zu st\u00fcrzen. Mit Unterst\u00fctzung der Demokraten wurde ein entsprechender Antrag am Mittwoch mit 359 zu 43 Stimmen abgelehnt. Greene geh\u00f6rt wie Johnson den Republikanern an. Sie hatte zuvor angek\u00fcndigt, Johnson st\u00fcrzen zu wollen.\n\nGem\u00e4\u00df den parlamentarischen Regeln des Repr\u00e4sentantenhauses kann ein einzelner Abgeordneter eine Abstimmung", "fra": "Quelques mois apr\u00e8s avoir obtenu la t\u00eate de l'ancien \" speaker \" de la Chambre, Kevin McCarthy, Marjorie Taylor Greene, proche de Donald Trump, souhaite cette fois destituer le pr\u00e9sident r\u00e9publicain de la Chambre des repr\u00e9sentants, Mike Johnson.\n\nUne \u00e9lue de la droite dure am\u00e9ricaine, Marjorie Taylor Greene, a formellement d\u00e9clench\u00e9 mercredi 8 mai 2024 une motion vou\u00e9e \u00e0 l'\u00e9chec pour destituer le pr\u00e9sident r\u00e9publicain de la Chambre des repr\u00e9sentants, Mike Johnson.\n\nLa parlementaire"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Georgia (U.S. state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Activism/Strategies", "label": "dmoz/Society/Activism/Strategies", "wgt": 77}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Gay,_Lesbian,_and_Bisexual/Politics", "label": "dmoz/Society/Gay, Lesbian, and Bisexual/Politics", "wgt": 72}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Green", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Green", "wgt": 74}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 95}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 405, "deu": 24, "fra": 7}, "sentiment": -0.03529411764705881}
{"uri": "2024-05-350013409", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:23:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:23:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:55:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/may/09/greene-fails-in-attempt-to-oust-house-speaker/", "title": "Greene fails in attempt to oust House speaker", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a sudden move Wednesday to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of former President Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene, of Georgia, criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAs she recited the grievance-laden measure that lasted more than 10 minutes, Republicans lined up on the House floor to shake Johnson's hand and pat him on the back.\n\n\"Given a choice between advancing Republican priorities or allying with Democrats to preserve his own personal power, Johnson regularly chooses to ally himself with Democrats,\" Greene said, reading from her resolution.\n\nShe concluded with the official call for his removal: \"Now, therefore be it resolved that the office of the speaker of the House of Representatives is hereby declared to be vacant.\"\n\nNo sooner had Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the House speaker from his office than Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise of Louisiana countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now. Seven Democrats voted \"present\" and 32 voted against putting the motion down, with the others joining Republicans in helping Johnson keep the House speakership.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own House speaker, an unheard-of level of party turmoil, with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nThe tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP in the Trump era. Without Democratic help, Johnson likely would have faced a more dismal outcome.\n\nAll told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-House speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, which was a first in U.S. history. And the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the House speaker.\n\nJohnson said he hoped it \"is the end of the personality politics.\"\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, including Trump, GOP lawmakers filtered toward Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican House speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson, of Louisiana, marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the House speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nTrump had also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago last month for support, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the House speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of House voting, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election. He urged Republicans to table Greene's motion.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the House speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote -- putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the House speaker and being seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nMassie and fellow Republican Paul Gosar, of Arizona, were the only ones who had publicly said they would support Greene in her efforts to recall Johnson.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the House speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust Johnson, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nRep. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene, \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote most likely would have ended differently for Johnson, who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy as House speaker and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid repeating ahead of the November election.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Lisa Mascaro, Kevin Freking, Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri of The Associated Press and by Catie Edmondson, Carl Hulse and Kayla Guo of The New York Times.\n\nRep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., joined by Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., speaks to reporters after she tried and failed to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos, at the Capitol in Washington, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., a staunch ally of former President Donald Trump, is threatening to oust Johnson from his leadership post, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)\n\nRep. {"uri": "8119089041", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:00:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:00:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:00:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://floridapolitics.com/archives/673454-house-rejects-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-remove-mike-johnson-from-office/", "title": "House rejects Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to remove Mike Johnson from office", "body": "A total of 11 Republicans voted against a motion to table, but this time most Democrats didn't join in.\n\nHardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action Wednesday to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, the Georgia Republican stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as Speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the Speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own Speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nThe tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP in the Trump era. Without Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome.\n\nAll told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history. And the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the Speaker.\n\nJohnson said he hoped it \"is the end of the personality politics.\"\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, including Trump, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican Speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nTrump had also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago last month for support, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the Speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of House voting, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election. He urged Republicans to table Greene's motion.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, a Kentucky Republican, a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, a South Dakota Republican, said of those trying to remove the Speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the Speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nRep. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, a New York Republican, called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the Speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\n___\n\nRepublished with permission of The Associated Press.", "source": {"uri": "floridapolitics.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Florida Politics - Campaigns & Elections. Lobbying & Government."}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@floridapolitics.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-349740102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:21:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:21:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:08:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-oust-speaker-mike-johnson-but-chaos-lingers/article_ae503506-9d15-5d3c-a350-526019b61dba.html", "title": "House rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, but chaos lingers", "body": "Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., joined by Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., speaks to reporters after she tried and failed to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos, at the Capitol in Washington, Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Democrats and Republicans does not guarantee an end to the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats to wield power.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "8118498393", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:14:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:14:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:13:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/may/08/house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-t/", "title": "House rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, but chaos lingers", "body": "J. Scott Applewhite / AP\n\nSpeaker of the House Mike Johnson, R-La., speaks during a news conference amid threats that Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., a staunch ally of former President Donald Trump, is threatening to oust Johnson from his leadership post, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, May 7, 2024.\n\nBy Lisa Mascaro and Kevin Freking, Associated Press\n\nWednesday, May 8, 2024 | 10 p.m.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Republicans and Democrats tired of the turmoil does not guarantee an end to the GOP chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats wield power.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the Republican speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.", Marjorie Taylor Greene", "body": "Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Democrats and Republicans does not guarantee an end to the political chaos.One of Donald Trumps biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of transgressions she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a 95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats to wield power.\n\nHardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Democrats and Republicans does not guarantee an end to the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats to wield power. Colleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\" After Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\" It's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history. While the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP. Without Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history. But by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker. Even though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. ''I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law. But in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution. Johnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\" Highly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now. \"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival. Asked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\" The move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump. Greene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him. \"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.'' He said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, ''I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\" Reps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\" Rep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare. Last year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him. Ousting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\n(This Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to oust Speaker...", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Republicans and Democrats tired of the turmoil does not guarantee an end to the GOP chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump\u00b4s biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats wield power.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson\u00b4s leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the Republican speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I\u00b4ve said from the beginning, and I\u00b4ve made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I\u00b4ll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nSpeaker of the House Mike Johnson, R-La., speaks during a news conference amid threats that Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., a staunch ally of former President Donald Trump, is threatening to oust Johnson from his leadership post, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)\n\nIt\u00b4s the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers - any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia\u00b4s invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene\u00b4s resolution - ensuring Johnson\u00b4s job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I\u00b4m proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They\u00b4re pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn\u00b4t represent the Republican Party. I\u00b4m tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That\u00b4s all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker\u00b4s office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.\n\nRep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., speaks to reporters after she tried and failed to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos, at the Capitol in Washington, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)\n\nRep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., joined by Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., speaks to reporters after she tried and failed to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos, at the Capitol in Washington, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)\n\nRep. {"uri": "2024-05-349648278", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:37:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:37:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:06:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-remove-speaker-mike-johnson-from-office/article_15d0de7d-36b0-53db-b98c-f826497c15ae.html", "title": "House rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to remove Speaker Mike Johnson from office", "body": "Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., joined by Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., speaks to reporters after she tried and failed to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos, at the Capitol in Washington, Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action Wednesday to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nThe tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP in the Trump era. Without Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome.\n\nAll told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history. And the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nJohnson said he hoped it \"is the end of the personality politics.\"\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, including Trump, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nTrump had also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago last month for support, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of House voting, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election. He urged Republicans to table Greene's motion.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "8119106465", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:12:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:12:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:11:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/us-politics/article-us-house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-oust-speaker/", "title": "U.S. House rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, but chaos lingers", "body": "Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Republicans and Democrats tired of the turmoil does not guarantee an end to the GOP chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats wield power.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the Republican speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers - any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution - ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gimenez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Globe and Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118274376", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:10:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:10:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:10:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/486471/House-quickly-rejects-Rep-Marjorie-Taylor-Greene-s-effort-to-remove-Speaker-Johnson-from-office", "title": "House quickly rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to remove Speaker Johnson from office - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., joined by Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., speaks to reporters after she tried and failed to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos, at the Capitol in Washington, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)\n\nHardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action Wednesday to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene of Georgia criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nNo sooner than Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, the Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nThe tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP as it redefines its mission in the Trump era. Without Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome.\n\nAll told 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history. And the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nJohnson said he hoped it \"is the end of the personality politics.\"\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, including Trump, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package with funds for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nTrump had also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago last month for support, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of House voting, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election. He urged Republicans to table Greene's motion.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Gim\u00e9nez"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associated_Press", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Associated Press"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Committee", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Republican National Committee"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Social media"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Florida"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Florida"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Activism/Strategies", "label": "dmoz/Society/Activism/Strategies", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Kidnapping", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Kidnapping", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Gay,_Lesbian,_and_Bisexual/Politics", "label": "dmoz/Society/Gay, Lesbian, and Bisexual/Politics", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Democracy", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Democracy", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Green", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Green", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 98}], "image": "https://www.castanet.net/content/2024/5/20240508190552-663c10e56013bbf0db33393ajpeg_p3794914.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9551299", "eventUri": "eng-9551299", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2, "wgt": 220, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-350267979", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:13:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:13:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:12:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://capitolhillblue.com/node/100660", "title": "House keeps Johnson as Speaker, slaps down Greene's efforts", "body": "Rep. Greene, a big supporter of Donald Trump, was booed by Republicans when she kept trying to ouse the speaker\n\nHard-line Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Republicans and Democrats tired of the turmoil does not guarantee an end to the GOP chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats to wield power.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the Republican speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "2024-05-349761302", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:55:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:55:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:08:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/09/house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-oust-speaker-mike-johnson-but-chaos-lingers/", "title": "House rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, but chaos lingers", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Republicans and Democrats tired of the turmoil does not guarantee an end to the GOP chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats wield power.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the Republican speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.",
