{"uri": "8118859348", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:34:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:34:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:33:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/may/09/house-quickly-rejects-greenes-effort-to-remove/", "title": "House quickly rejects Greene's  effort to remove Johnson from office", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action Wednesday to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene of Georgia criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nNo sooner than Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, the Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have tried to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\n\"We need steady hands at the wheel,\" Johnson said afterward. \"The country desperately needs a functioning Congress.\"\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package with funds for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\n\"I just have to do my job every day,\" Johnson said Monday.\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\nTrump also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago for a visit, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of the vote, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election.\n\n\"This is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote -- putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\nThe tally showed the strength, but also the weakness, of her effort, as most lawmakers voted to move past the infighting and allow the Republican speaker, just six months in the office, to keep the gavel.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was brought to a standstill when eight Republicans voted to oust Kevin McCarthy from the speaker's office, and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, throwing the chamber into turmoil with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid before seeking voter support in the November election.\n\nSpeaker of the House Mike Johnson, R-La., speaks during a news conference amid threats that Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., a staunch ally of former President Donald Trump, is threatening to oust Johnson from his leadership post, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. {"uri": "2024-05-349656316", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:55:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:55:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:34:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.oneidadispatch.com/2024/05/08/house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-remove-speaker-mike-johnson-from-office/", "title": "House rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to remove Speaker Mike Johnson from office", "body": "By LISA MASCARO and KEVIN FREKING (Associated Press)\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action Wednesday to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nThe tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP in the Trump era. Without Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome.\n\nAll told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history. And the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nJohnson said he hoped it \"is the end of the personality politics.\"\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, including Trump, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nTrump had also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago last month for support, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of House voting, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election. He urged Republicans to table Greene's motion.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\n__\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.", {"uri": "8118219960", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:00:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:00:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:59:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://ksltv.com/642643/house-quickly-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-remove-speaker-johnson-from-office-2/", "title": "House quickly rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to remove Speaker Johnson from office", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action Wednesday to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene of Georgia criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nNo sooner than Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, the Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\nDemocrats say they will save Speaker Mike Johnson's job if Republicans try to oust him\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have tried to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, including Trump, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nJohnson said the \"distraction\" was behind him and said he hoped it \"is the end of the personality politics.\"\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package with funds for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nMarjorie Taylor Greene calls on Johnson to resign after foreign aid bills pass\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Green from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nTrump had also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago last month for support, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of House voting, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election. He urged Republicans to table Greene's motion.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nJohnson won't change rules over removing him from speakership after hardliners revolt\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\nThe tally showed the strength, but also the weakness, of her effort, as most lawmakers voted to move past the infighting and allow the Republican speaker, just six months in the office, to keep the gavel.\n\n\"The Democrats saved him,\" Greene said afterward.\n\nWithout Democratic support, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was brought to a standstill when eight Republicans voted to oust Kevin McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him, the first such removal of a House speaker in U.S. history.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, throwing the chamber into turmoil with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid before seeking voter support in the November election.\n\n__\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick and Michelle Price contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.01960784313725483, "wgt": 218, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-349744813", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:29:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:29:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:08:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2024-05-09/house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-oust-speaker-mike-johnson-but-chaos-lingers", "title": "House Rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's Effort to Oust Speaker Mike Johnson, but Chaos Lingers", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Democrats and Republicans does not guarantee an end to the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats to wield power.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8118480109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:57:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:57:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:56:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.greenfieldreporter.com/2024/05/09/house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-oust-speaker-mike-johnson-but-chaos-lingers/", "title": "House rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, but chaos lingers - The Daily Reporter - Greenfield Indiana", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Republicans and Democrats tired of the turmoil does not guarantee an end to the GOP chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats wield power.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the Republican speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.", But Greene soldiered on, criticising Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the Republican speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in US history.\n\nMore trouble ahead\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in US history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the US to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nA rare moment of bipartisanship\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics.\n\nJeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nCalls to punish Greene\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Representative Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRepresentative Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognised for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nRepresentative Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRepresentative Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, Marjorie Taylor Greene's Effort to Oust Speaker Mike Johnson, but Chaos Lingers | LatestLY", "body": "Washington, May 9 (AP) Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Democrats and Republicans does not guarantee an end to the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats to wield power.\n\nAlso Read | Israel-Hamas War: 30 Killed During IDF's Continuing Ground Assault in Gaza's Rafah.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAlso Read | Barron Trump Steps Into Political Arena: Donald Trump's Youngest Son To Make Political Debut As Florida Delegate to the Republican Convention.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election. (AP)", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LatestLY"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_to_vacate", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, {"uri": "2024-05-349661070", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:04:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:04:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:06:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-remove-speaker-mike-johnson-from-office/article_642fe6a0-9747-5610-9283-6a0f31506385.html", "title": "House rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to remove Speaker Mike Johnson from office", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action Wednesday to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nThe tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP in the Trump era. Without Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome.\n\nAll told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history. And the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nJohnson said he hoped it \"is the end of the personality politics.\"\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, including Trump, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nTrump had also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago last month for support, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of House voting, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election. He urged Republicans to table Greene's motion.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this section\n\nDecline in New Industrial Manufacturing Planned Industrial Projects in April 2024 ACES Quality Management Partners with Infrrd to Provide AI-Powered Intelligent Mortgage Document Processing Long Time Ferret Activist Pat Wright Files Lawsuit Against California Fish and Game Commission President Eric Sklar", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 {"uri": "8118318627", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:02:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:02:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:02:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/us-representatives-move-to-oust-house-speaker-mike-johnson-rejected-2536892-2024-05-09", "title": "US Representative's move to oust House speaker Mike Johnson rejected", "body": "Hardline Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action on Wednesday to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene criticised Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in US history.\n\nThe tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP in the Trump era. Without Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome.\n\nAll told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in US history. And the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nJohnson said he hoped it \"is the end of the personality politics.\"\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, including Trump, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the US to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nTrump had also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago last month for support, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod to approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of House voting, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election. He urged Republicans to table Greene's motion.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Representative Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRepresentative Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognised for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nRepresentative Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRepresentative Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly month-long search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "India {"uri": "8118145865", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:30:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:30:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:29:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2932629-house-soundly-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-resolution-to-oust-speaker-johnson", "title": "House soundly rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's resolution to oust Speaker Johnson | Politics", "body": "Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's attempt to oust Speaker Mike Johnson failed, with an overwhelming majority voting to table it. Despite Greene's allegations, Johnson's leadership remains, supported by both Republicans and Democrats. This follows a previous attempt to oust Kevin McCarthy last year. Greene's move carries political risks as it requires colleagues to take a stance on internal party turmoil.\n\nHardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action Wednesday to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos. One of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene of Georgia criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\" No sooner than Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, the Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have tried to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\n''We need steady hands at the wheel,\" Johnson said afterward. \"The country desperately needs a functioning Congress.'' The Georgia Republican had vowed she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package with funds for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law. But in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution. Johnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\" \"I just have to do my job every day,\" Johnson said Monday.\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now. Trump also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago for a visit, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of the vote, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election.\n\n\"This is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur. Greene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\nThe tally showed the strength, but also the weakness, of her effort, as most lawmakers voted to move past the infighting and allow the Republican speaker, just six months in the office, to keep the gavel. Last year, the House chamber was brought to a standstill when eight Republicans voted to oust Kevin McCarthy from the speaker's office, and Democrats declined to help save him. Ousting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, throwing the chamber into turmoil with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid before seeking voter support in the November election.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, {"uri": "8118196048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:30:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:30:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:29:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.wral.com/story/rep-marjorie-taylor-greene-triggers-effort-to-remove-house-speaker-mike-johnson-from-office/21421077/", "title": "House quickly rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to remove Speaker Johnson from office", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in sudden action Wednesday to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, her long-shot effort swiftly and resoundingly rejected by Democrats and Republicans tired of the political chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nGreene of Georgia criticized Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nNo sooner than Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, the Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have tried to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party turmoil with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels, including Trump, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nJohnson said the \"distraction\" was behind him and said he hoped it \"is the end of the personality politics.\"\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package with funds for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Green from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nTrump had also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago last month for support, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nAhead of House voting, Trump said on social media, \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" but he said Republicans need to be fighting now to defeat Democrats in the November election. He urged Republicans to table Greene's motion.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said, to oust the speaker.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\nThe tally showed the strength, but also the weakness, of her effort, as most lawmakers voted to move past the infighting and allow the Republican speaker, just six months in the office, to keep the gavel.\n\n\"The Democrats saved him,\" Greene said afterward.\n\nWithout Democratic support, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was brought to a standstill when eight Republicans voted to oust Kevin McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him, the first such removal of a House speaker in U.S. history.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, throwing the chamber into turmoil with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid before seeking voter support in the November election.\n\n__\n\nAssociated {"uri": "8118186204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:16:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:16:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:15:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.opb.org/article/2024/05/08/bid-to-oust-speaker-johnson-fails-but-gop-turmoil-remains/", "title": "Bid to oust Speaker Johnson fails but GOP turmoil remains", "body": "The House voted overwhelmingly to set aside a motion by Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene to call a vote to remove Mike Johnson as speaker of the House. The vote was 359-43 with seven members voting present. 196 Republicans and 163 Democrats voted to table the motion.\n\n\"Hopefully, this is the end of the personality politics and the frivolous character assassination that has defined the 118th Congress,\" Johnson told reporters after the vote. \"It's regrettable. It's not who we are as Americans and we're better than this -- we need to get beyond it.\"\n\nAs promised, House Democrats largely supported Johnson in setting aside the call for his removal, making Greene's endeavor symbolic. Only 10 Republicans voted alongside Greene.\n\nThe vote was the culmination of weeks of threats from the Georgia Republican.\n\nRelated: House Democratic leaders say they would help save Speaker Johnson's job\n\nWhile the measure failed, Greene and other Republicans remain angry with Johnson's reliance on votes from Democrats to pass major legislation.\n\n\"Mike Johnson worked with [Senate Majority Leader] Chuck Schumer rather than the conference and gave Joe Biden and the Democrats everything they wanted -- no different from how a Speaker Hakeem Jeffries would have done,\" Greene said on the floor, reading a litany of criticisms against Johnson.\n\n\"This is the uni-party for the American people watching,\" Greene said as the House chamber erupted into boos as she brought forward the motion to vacate.\n\nGreene has been weighing whether to trigger a vote to oust Johnson since she filed the motion in March, after objecting to his negotiating with Democrats on a $1.2 trillion spending package that ultimately passed the House with more Democratic support than Republican support.\n\nLast week, Greene threatened to move forward with the motion to vacate after the House voted on an aid bill for Ukraine.\n\nTwo Republican co-sponsored her resolution -- Arizona Rep. Paul Gosar and Kentucky Rep. Thomas Massie.\n\nGreene met twice this week with Johnson, including an over two-hour meeting on Monday.\n\n\"Everybody was listening -- it wasn't a shouting match,\" Massie said of the Monday meeting. \"[Greene] and I decided to give Speaker Johnson one last chance to say he's going to be with the Republicans and not with the Democrats, and there are some litmus tests on that.\"\n\nGreene and Massie said those litmus tests include no additional funding for Ukraine, no funding toward the special counsel investigation into former President Donald Trump, and Johnson only bringing legislation to the floor that has the support of the majority of the GOP conference.\n\nRelated: Majorie Taylor Greene is planning a vote next week to oust Speaker Johnson\n\nIn an appearance on Steve Bannon's \"War Room\" podcast Tuesday, Greene said she also wants twelve separate appropriations bills and not another omnibus led by Schumer \"rammed down our throat.\"\n\n\"That will not be tolerated again,\" she said, adding that if House Republicans don't get the twelve distinct bills, she wants to see a one percent cut to spending.\n\nAlthough members of the hardline House Freedom Caucus have expressed dissatisfaction with Johnson's actions in his short tenure as speaker, most say they still don't want to put the conference through another speaker fight.\n\nGreene has also been under pressure from former President Trump. Greene and Trump spoke over the weekend and Trump urged her to back down, according to a source familiar with the conversation.\n\nAfter the vote on Wednesday, Trump took to social media to request that Republican members vote to table the motion.\n\n\"We're not in a position of voting on a Motion to Vacate,\" he wrote. \"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time.\"", "source": {"uri": "opb.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "opb"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Speaker of the United States House of Representatives"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Democratic Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Republican Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Johnson_(Louisiana_politician)", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Mike Johnson (Louisiana politician)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/118th_United_States_Congress", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "118th United States Congress"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marjorie_Taylor_Greene", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Marjorie Taylor Greene"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Massie", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Massie"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "8118896819", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:58:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:58:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:57:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://nationalnewswatch.com/2024/05/09/house-rejects-rep-marjorie-taylor-greenes-effort-to-oust-speaker-mike-johnson-but-chaos-lingers", "title": "House rejects Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to oust Speaker...", "body": "One of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats to wield power.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. But Greene soldiered on, criticizing Johnson's leadership as \"pathetic, weak and unacceptable.\"\n\nAfter Greene triggered the vote on her motion to vacate the speaker from his office, Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling first for a vote to table it.\n\nAn overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning, and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job,\" Johnson said afterward. \"And I'll let the chips fall where they may. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 11 Republicans voted to proceed with Greene's effort, more than it took to oust then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nBut by relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\nEven though Trump provided a needed nod of support for Johnson at crucial moments, it's not bankable going forward. The former president posed an idle warning about potentially ousting the speaker as voting was getting underway.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" Trump said on social media.\n\nTrump also made clear he still valued Greene, perhaps his biggest ally in the House, even as he rejected her proposal. \"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" he said as he urged Republicans to table her motion.\n\nAs Greene pressed ahead with the snap vote, GOP lawmakers filtered towards Johnson, giving him pats on the back and grasping his shoulder to assure him of their support.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed weeks ago she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance the foreign aid package for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk to approve the foreign aid, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nHighly unusual, the boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote - putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., a group of other Republicans gathered on the steps trying to shift the attention away from her and make their own views known.\n\nRep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., said of those trying to remove the speaker, \"They're pretty good at getting attention, but they have not been recognized for their ability to get things done.\"\n\nHe said if they keep pushing to oust the speaker, \"I think you can expect more of the same: Failure.\"\n\nReps. Carlos Gim\u00e9nez, a Florida Republican, said of Greene: \"She doesn't represent the Republican Party. I'm tired of of this being the face or the voice of the party and getting attention. That's all she wants, is the attention.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., called for Greene and Massie to be punished for their actions.\n\nHad Democrats not taken the unusual move to help, the vote would most likely have ended differently for Johnson who holds one of the slimmest majorities in the House in modern times, with no votes to spare.\n\nLast year, the House chamber was hurled into chaos when eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy from the speaker's office and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, bringing the chamber to a standstill with an episode Republicans wanted to avoid ahead of the November election.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick, Michelle Price and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.\n\nLisa Mascaro And Kevin Freking, The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "nationalnewswatch.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "National Newswatch"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Greene's effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, but chaos remains", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene tried and failed in a brazen push to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, but the resounding rejection by Republicans and Democrats tired of the turmoil does not guarantee an end to the GOP chaos.\n\nOne of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor late Wednesday and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker, from his passage of a $95 billion national security package with aid for Ukraine to his reliance on Democrats wield power.\n\nAdvertisementAdvertisement\n\nColleagues booed in protest. In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nAdvertisementSaved by Democrats\n\nWhile the outcome temporarily calms the latest source of House disruption, the vote tally shows the strengths but also the stark limits of Johnson's hold on the gavel, and the risks ahead for any Republican trying to lead the GOP.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, showed the exhaustion in Congress over the far-right antics. Jeffries and his leadership team had said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" Jeffries said after the vote.\n\nBut Democrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nAdvertisement'Proud of what I did'\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, a high-profile provocateur who has moved to the forefront of the party with her own massive following and proximity to Trump.\n\nGreene was determined to force her colleagues to be on the record with their vote -- putting them in the politically uncomfortable position of backing the speaker and seen as joining forces with Democrats to save him.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWhile reporters and camera crews crowded around Greene and ally Rep.
