{"uri": "8118636197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:05:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:05:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:04:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.dailysignal.com/2024/05/09/greenes-gambit-fails-speaker-johnson-survives-high-stakes-ouster-attempt/", "title": "House Speaker Mike Johnson Survives GOP Ouster Attempt", "body": "Get your FREE digital copy of The Heritage Foundation's Founders' Almanac.\n\nSpeaker Mike Johnson, R-La., can breathe a little easier now that more than 80% of his House colleagues put an end to the latest drama gripping Capitol Hill.\n\nSix months after ascending to the speakership, a bipartisan coalition of Democrats and Republicans overwhelmingly voted to table a motion to vacate the chair -- the House's terminology for removing its leader. The final vote was 359-43; seven voted present and 21 others didn't cast a vote. (See how your representative voted.)\n\n\"Hopefully, this is the end of the personality politics and the frivolous character assassination that has defined the 118th Congress,\" Johnson said after Wednesday's vote. \"It's regrettable. It's not who we are as Americans and we're better than this. We need to get beyond it.\"\n\nDon't count on it.\n\nJohnson may have survived the vote, but the anger toward him among some Republicans likely won't subside anytime soon.\n\nRep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., who offered the motion to vacate, bemoaned the \"uniparty\" that saved the speaker.\n\nPetty squabbles and personal recriminations are nothing new for the House of Representatives. History offers many lessons. But today's divisions -- among the majority party, nonetheless -- seem irreparable.\n\nThe GOP's narrow House majority after the November 2022 election emboldened rank-and-file conservatives to demand much-needed changes. After multiple rounds of voting in January 2023, then-Rep. Kevin McCarthy acquiesced to their requests and secured the votes needed to be speaker.\n\n>>> 20 Lawmakers Stood Up to the Washington Establishment. This is Their Story.\n\nWith any member of the narrowly divided House able to initiate the process of removing the speaker, it was perhaps inventible that Johnson would eventually face the same scenario as McCarthy. And when Johnson opted to rely on Democrats to pass bills, that's precisely what happened.\n\nTo avoid a showdown, Johnson reportedly spent hours meeting with Greene this week, only to have her deliver a fiery floor speech that was met by a chorus of boos and jeers. When she wasn't being interrupted, Greene accused the speaker of selling out his party and turning over House control to Democrats.\n\nSitting by her side, Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., repeatedly came to Greene's aid.\n\nTheir grievances against Johnson include his decision to pass government spending bills with Democrat support, expel embattled New York Republican George Santos from the House, and advance a $95 billion foreign aid bill over the objections of conservatives.\n\nGreene even managed to work in a defense of ousted Speaker McCarthy, whom both she and Massie considered an ally. Hours later, Massie doubled down on their defense of McCarthy by contrasting him as a favorable option to Johnson.\n\nSorry, Mr. Speaker, personality politics reign supreme.\n\nIn reality, Johnson will never know just how many Republicans want to see him gone beyond Greene, Massie, and Rep. Paul Gosar, R-Ariz. That's because before Greene's motion to vacate came to vote, the House opted to table it.\n\nOf the 11 Republicans against motion to table, only a few explained their vote. But it's safe to say not all were aligned with Greene, despite what Massie suggested.\n\nAt least three said not to interpret their opposition as an indication of their feelings toward Johnson.\n\nRep. Warren Davidson, R-Ohio, opposed Greene's motion to vacate even though he joined her on the procedural vote. \"One should not be viewed as a proxy for the other,\" he said.\n\nRep. Victoria Spartz, R-Ind., declared her opposition to Green's motion to vacate but opposed the effort to table it. \"I fought a lot to change Pelosi rules and have more accountability on the speaker in Congress,\" she explained.\n\nAnd finally, Rep. Eric Burlison, R-Mo., put it bluntly when he said that \"joining Democrats in a motion to table was more than I could stomach.\"\n\nWhile Johnson's critics will continue to complain that Democrats helped save him, more Republicans had his back Wednesday.\n\nSo where does Johnson go from here?\n\nHe most certainly shouldn't let Democrat Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., dictate the chamber's agenda for the next six month. Across the halls of the Capitol, Senate Democrats are already plotting to change the narrative on border security, one of President Joe Biden's greatest vulnerabilities.\n\nA sustained effort by the House to elevate the issue of illegal immigration is needed now more than ever. Republicans took an important step Wednesday to pass the Equal Representation Act, which prevents illegal aliens from influencing congressional representation and the Electoral College.\n\n>>> House Passes Bill to Restore Citizenship Question to Census\n\nThose same lawmakers must redouble their efforts on other fronts, including the strong measures already adopted in the Secure the Border Act (HR 2).\n\nWith only a few must-pass pieces of legislation remaining this Congress, there's precious little time to squander the opportunity.", "source": {"uri": "dailysignal.com", "dataType": "news", Greene's bid to seek retribution by unseating the speaker with a \"motion to vacate\" won support from only two other members of her party: Massie and Representative Paul Gosar.\n\nThe U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday quickly defeated an effort by firebrand Republican Marjorie Taylor Greene to remove fellow Republican Speaker Mike Johnson from his leadership role. Democrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote to protect Johnson's speakership, in a bid to avoid a replay of the chaos that followed in October when Republicans ousted his predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nGreene's move represented a rare Republican defiance of presidential candidate Donald Trump, who had voiced support for Johnson and called the drive to oust him \"unfortunate.\" Standing flanked by fellow Republican Thomas Massie, Greene criticized Johnson for a string of compromises with Democrats, who hold a majority in the Senate.\n\n\"Excuses like 'this is just how you have to govern in divided government' are pathetic, weak and unacceptable,\" Greene said of Johnson. \"Even with our razor-thin Republican majority we could have at least secured the border.\" But the chamber erupted in taunts and cheers at points as Greene read her resolution, with Democrats at times chanting \"Hakeem, Hakeem,\" a reference to their party leader Hakeem Jeffries, in an echo of the many times they voted for him as speaker during Republicans' multiple rounds of voting for speaker since the current House was seated in January 2021.\n\nJohnson has angered many hardliners within his razor-thin 217-213 Republican majority this year, by enacting bipartisan spending measures to avoid government shutdowns and aid U.S. allies including Ukraine, without insisting on strict security measures for the U.S.-Mexico border that Democrats reject. Johnson could be seen walking around the House floor after Greene began her call on Wednesday for his ouster, with Republican supporters shaking his hand and patting him on the back.\n\nThe situation has bolstered Jeffries, who agreed to save Johnson from ouster after freeing Congress from the roadblock of Republican infighting by delivering crucial Democratic support for must-pass bills. Greene's bid to seek retribution by unseating the speaker with a \"motion to vacate\" won support from only two other members of her party: Massie and Representative Paul Gosar.\n\n(This story has not Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga. to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson on Wednesday evening, with Democrats and Republicans banding together to extend a lifeline to the embattled speaker.\n\nThe vote to table the motion was 359-43. Greene, who began threatening the motion to vacate last month, had been negotiating with Johnson for days and as of Tuesday appeared to back away from the threat. But that changed Wednesday afternoon, as she announced plans to move forward with the vote. It was short-lived.\n\nThe effort was widely expected to fail. House Democrats, happy with Johnson's decision to move aid to Ukraine, vowed to protect him from a motion to vacate last week.\n\nGreene's antics had frustrated rank-and-file House Republicans, some of whom worried about the political impact of a GOP embroiled in divisions. Those concerns were shared by former President Donald Trump, who has offered support for Johnson and reportedly pressed Greene to back off on a phone call last week.\n\n\"I will give her this credit. Austin Scott, R-Ga. was among the scores of Republicans caught off-guard by Greene forcing a snap vote on Johnson. In contrast, every Democrat voted to oust Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) as speaker last year after Matt Gaetz (R-FL) filed a motion to vacate.\n\nAccording to The New York Times, members of the minority party in the House have never before voted to prop up the other party's speaker, and the move demonstrates strong bipartisanship for foreign interventions. Democrats had signaled that they would protect Johnson if he held a vote on Ukraine aid.\n\nGreene and a few other Republicans have been critical of Johnson for putting forward the foreign military aid bills without getting any concessions on border and migration policies. \"Given a choice between advancing Republican priorities or allying with Democrats to preserve his own personal power, Johnson regularly chooses to ally himself with Democrats,\" she said on the floor of the House.\n\nAfter the vote, Greene told reporters that the Democrats \"now control Speaker Johnson.\"\n\nHakeem Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nThe vote, which under House rules is required within two days, could happen imminently.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package with funds for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\n\"I just have to do my job every day,\" Johnson said Monday.\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team has said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\nTrump also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago for a visit, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, R-Ga., a high-profile provocateur.\n\nForcing the vote could bring the House chamber to a standstill, as happened last year when eight Republicans voted to ousted Kevin McCarthy from the speaker's office, and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOr it could be over in a matter of minutes, as Democrats join Republicans to table the effort.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP The difference is no Democrats voted to save McCarthy last year, while most sided with Johnson on Wednesday.\n\n\"I would say the Democrats validated him to the rest of the Congress,\" Greene said after the vote. \"Democrats saved him, Nancy Pelosi voted for him -- Nancy Pelosi doesn't vote for Republicans unless she has full control of the House -- Hakeem Jeffries, the entire leadership team, Jerry Nadler, Jamie Raskin, they all voted for Mike Johnson. That is the most terrifying thing to our constituents and to the American people.\"\n\nGreene brought the motion to vacate forward during the House vote series and was instantly met with loud boos from her own party. She launched into a lengthy speech detailing her grievances against Johnson.\n\nWhile Greene was speaking on the House floor Wednesday on moving her motion forward, several members of the Main Street Caucus left the chamber and gathered before reporters on the Capitol steps. Chairman Dusty Johnson (R-SD) and several others blasted Greene for throwing a \"tantrum.\"\n\n\"All of us in life get to decide how we handle disappointment: you can be productive or you can be destructive,\" the South Dakota congressman said. \"Ms. Marjorie Taylor Greene is choosing destructive.\"\n\n\"Most of us by the time we turn 12 years old figured out the tantrums don't actually work, {"uri": "8118199215", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:33:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:33:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:33:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2932646-us-house-quickly-defeats-greenes-effort-to-oust-speaker-johnson", "title": "US House quickly defeats Greene's effort to oust Speaker Johnson | Politics", "body": "Democrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote to protect Johnson's speakership, in a bid to avoid a replay of the chaos that occurred in October when Republicans ousted his predecessor, Kevin McCarthy. Greene's move represented a rare Republican defiance of presidential candidate Donald Trump, who in a social media post following the House vote on Wednesday, said it was \"not the time\" for Republicans to try to push out their own speaker.\n\nThe U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday swiftly and overwhelmingly defeated an effort by firebrand Republican Marjorie Taylor Greene to remove Speaker Mike Johnson, a fellow Republican, from his leadership role. Democrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote to protect Johnson's speakership, in a bid to avoid a replay of the chaos that occurred in October when Republicans ousted his predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nGreene's move represented a rare Republican defiance of presidential candidate Donald Trump, who in a social media post following the House vote on Wednesday, said it was \"not the time\" for Republicans to try to push out their own speaker. Greene's measure, known as a motion to vacate, showcased the disorder that has marked Republicans' slim 217-213 House majority, particularly since it had been clear that the effort would fail given Democrats' opposition.\n\n\"I appreciate the show of confidence from my colleagues to defeat this misguided effort,\" Johnson, 52, said following the vote. \"Hopefully this is the end of the character assassination that has characterized the current Congress.\" Multiple Republicans criticized Greene's move, including centrist Representative Marc Molinaro.\n\n\"This is not an individual who knows how to lead,\" Molinaro said of Greene. \"She's not an individual who knows how to negotiate. And she certainly doesn't seem to have any concern for the stability of the Congress or the people we represent.\" Greene stood flanked by fellow Republican Thomas Massie when she made her move against Johnson, criticizing him for a string of compromises with Democrats, who hold a majority in the Senate.\n\n\"Excuses like 'this is just how you have to govern in divided government' are pathetic, weak and unacceptable,\" Greene said of Johnson. \"Even with our razor-thin Republican majority we could have at least secured the border.\" TAUNTS AND JEERS\n\nThe chamber erupted in taunts and cheers at points as Greene read her resolution, with Democrats at times chanting \"Hakeem, Hakeem,\" a reference to their party leader, Hakeem Jeffries, in an echo of the many times they voted for him as speaker during Republicans' multiple rounds of voting for speaker since the current House was seated in January 2021. Johnson has angered many hardliners by enacting bipartisan spending measures to avoid government shutdowns and aid U.S. allies including Ukraine, without insisting on strict security measures for the U.S.-Mexico border that Democrats reject.\n\nThe House Republicans' border security bill had no chance of passing the Democratic-controlled Senate. A bipartisan compromise bill negotiated late last year and early this year in the Senate, with the Biden administration's approval, was killed by House and Senate Republicans at Trump's behest.\n\nJohnson could be seen walking around the House floor after Greene began her call on Wednesday for his ouster, with Republican supporters shaking his hand and patting him on the back. \"Republicans have to be fighting the Radical Left Democrats, and all the Damage they have done to our Country,\" Trump said in his Wednesday post. \"We're not in a position of voting on a Motion to Vacate. At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time.\"\n\nThe situation has bolstered Jeffries, who agreed to save Johnson from ouster after freeing Congress from the road block of Republican infighting by delivering crucial Democratic support for must-pass bills. Greene in remarks to reporters after the vote did not rule out trying to oust Johnson again.\n\nFor his part, Jeffries said he hoped to see House Republicans turn against party hardliners, saying, \"The only thing we ask of our House Republican colleagues is for traditional Republicans to further isolate the extreme MAGA Republican wing of the GOP, which has visited nothing but chaos and dysfunction on the American people.\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": Mike Johnson (R-La.) out of the speaker's office.\n\nRep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) filed the motion to vacate after a speech in which she accused Johnson of failing to defund the Department of Justice in order to stop its lawsuits against Trump.\n\nThe former president praised Greene even as he said that Republicans needed to be unified in his post on Truth Social.\n\n\"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene. She's got Spirit, she's got Fight, and I believe she'll be around, and on our side, for a long time to come,\" wrote Trump.\n\n\"Mike Johnson is a good man who is trying very hard.\"\n\n\"However, right now, Republicans have to be fighting the Radical Left Democrats, and all the Damage they have done to our Country,\" he added. \"With a Majority of One, shortly growing to three or four, we're not in a position of voting on a Motion to Vacate. I also wish certain things were done over the last period of two months, but we will get them done, together.\"\n\nHe went on to request Republicans vote to table the motion.\n\nGreene had previously said that she was upset that Johnson had not ended funding that went to Ukraine in its war against Russia's invasion. Only 11 Republicans voted to support the motion.\n\nJohnson had defended himself by responding, \"I'm the most conservative member who has ever held the gavel as speaker, but the reality of our numbers is our challenge.\"\n\n\"A failing act of political theater.\"\n\nAngry Republicans excoriated the effort in an impromptu media briefing outside the Capitol Building. Republican Rep. Dusty Johnson of South Dakota especially derided the motion.\n\n\"We know this motion is not going to do one thing to make America stronger, it's not gonna do one thing to deliver a conservative victory. It's going to sow discord and dissent, and by the way, it's going to fail. She is engaged in a failing act of political theater,\" said Johnson to reporters.\n\n\"What you have here is some of the mainstream members who are the adults, and we're gonna do what adults do,\" he added. \"We're going to ignore the tantrums and instead work to actually govern this country.\"\n\nRep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky was an avid supporter of the motion to remove Johnson, and he issued a bitter critique of the political situation after the vote.\n\n\"Vacating Kevin McCarthy was a huge mistake. Every Democrat voted to vacate him because he fought them tooth and nail,\" Massey said on social media.\n\n\"Keeping Mike Johnson is an even bigger mistake,\" he added. \"An overwhelming majority of democrats voted to keep him because he's given them everything they want.\"\n\nJohnson replaced Kevin McCarthy in October after a campaign that accused the former speaker of being weak and not supportive of Trump enough. Greene had praised the ascension of Johnson and took a selfie with him after the vote was successful.\n\n\"I just voted for Mike Johnson to be our next Speaker of the House! Mike has a conservative voting record and has committed to helping me move important legislation forward,\" she posted at the time.\n\nAfter the vote on Wednesday, she accused him of being the leader of the \"uniparty,\" including Democrats.\n\n\"Tonight, you saw the Uniparty in action. Nancy Pelosi, Hakeem Jeffries, and the rest of the Democrats saved Mike Johnson,\" she said in a pair of messages on social media.\n\nTrump finished his post on Wednesday promising that Republicans C. - The U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday rejected an effort by Georgia GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson in a 359 to 43 vote, with all Ohio's GOP members except Miami County Republican Warren Davidson voting to table her resolution.\n\nDavidson has previously expressed displeasure with Johnson's willingness to reach spending deals with Democrats, telling Fox News in January that voting to approve Johnson as speaker after California's Kevin McCarthy was removed from the job was one of the worst votes he'd cast in his congressional career.\n\nHe was the only Ohioan among 11 Republicans who supported Taylor Greene's effort. The vast majority of Republicans - 196 of them - joined with 163 Democrats to kill her motion to remove Johnson. Thirty-two Democrats voted against tabling it, and 7 Democrats voted \"present.\" All Ohio Democrats voted against Taylor Greene's measure except for Cincinnati's Greg Landsman, who missed the vote.\n\nOther Ohio Republicans argued that removing Johnson would paralyze Congress, as happened last year when Republicans spent weeks selecting a new Speaker after McCarthy was removed.\n\n\"I am proud to be a Conservative Republican,\" U.S. Rep. Max Miller, a Rocky River Republican posted on social media after the vote. \"I am proud to stand with @SpeakerJohnson.\"\n\nChampaign County GOP Rep. Jim Jordan, who unsuccessfully sought the speakership after McCarthy's departure, last week told Fox News it would be a mistake to remove Johnson.\n\n\"We need to be focused on Mike Johnson to stay as our speaker, we need to be focused on the election, which is now six months away,\" said Jordan, who chairs the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nAfter threatening for weeks to trigger a vote to remove Johnson, Taylor Greene brought her effort to the House floor after 5 p.m. Wednesday.\n\nTaylor Greene argued that Johnson should be ousted for failing to live up to his promises to pass conservative legislation, working with Democrats on spending bills, and relying on Democrats' votes on several occasions, among other perceived offenses. She maintained he's \"\"ill equipped to handle the rigors of the job of the speaker of the House.\"\n\n\"Our country is nearly $35 trillion in debt, and about $40 billion are added to the debt every day,\" Greene said on the House of Representatives floor. \"Our border is overrun by illegal invaders and terrorists from over 160 countries. Our people are being killed by the hundreds every single day by fentanyl and Mike Johnson refuses to do anything about about it.\"\n\nAfter the vote, Johnson released a statement that said he appreciates \"the show of confidence from my colleagues to defeat this misguided effort, that is certainly what it was.\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning and I've made clear here every day, I intend to do my job, I intend to do what I believe to be the right thing, which is what I was elected to do, and let the chips fall where they may,\" he continued. \"In my view, that is She's got Spirit, she's got Fight, and I believe she'll be around, and on our side, for a long time to come,\" wrote Trump.\n\n\"Mike Johnson is a good man who is trying very hard.\"\n\n\"However, right now, Republicans have to be fighting the Radical Left Democrats, and all the Damage they have done to our Country,\" he added. \"With a Majority of One, shortly growing to three or four, we're not in a position of voting on a Motion to Vacate. I also wish certain things were done over the last period of two months, but we will get them done, together.\"\n\nHe went on to request Republicans vote to table the motion.\n\nGreene had previously said that she was upset that Johnson had not ended funding that went to Ukraine in its war against Russia's invasion. It's going to sow discord and dissent, and by the way, it's going to fail. She is engaged in a failing act of political theater,\" said Johnson to reporters.\n\n\"What you have here is some of the mainstream members who are the adults, and we're gonna do what adults do,\" he added. \"We're going to ignore the tantrums and instead work to actually govern this country.\"\n\nRep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky was an avid supporter of the motion to remove Johnson, and he issued a bitter critique of the political situation after the vote.\n\n\"Vacating Kevin McCarthy was a huge mistake. Every Democrat voted to vacate him because he fought them tooth and nail,\" Massey said on social media.\n\n-- (@)\n\n\"Keeping Mike Johnson is an even bigger mistake,\" he added. \"An overwhelming majority of democrats voted to keep him because he's given them everything they want.\"\n\nJohnson replaced Kevin McCarthy in October after a campaign that accused the former speaker of being weak and not supportive of Trump enough. Greene had praised the ascension of Johnson and took a selfie with him after the vote was successful.\n\n\"I just voted for Mike Johnson to be our next Speaker of the House! Mike has a conservative voting record and has committed to helping me move important legislation forward,\" she posted at the time.\n\nAfter the vote on Wednesday, she accused him of being the leader of the \"uniparty,\" including Democrats.\n\n\"Tonight, you saw the Uniparty in action. {"uri": "2024-05-349761656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:56:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:56:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:29:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://arab.news/wn7xb", "title": "US House quickly defeats Republican hardliners' effort to oust", "body": "Hakeem Jeffries, the House's Democratic Party leader, said he hoped to see House Republicans turn against party hard-liners\n\nWASHINGTON: The US House of Representatives on Wednesday swiftly and overwhelmingly defeated an effort by firebrand Republican Marjorie Taylor Greene to remove Speaker Mike Johnson, a fellow Republican, from his leadership role.\n\nDemocrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote to protect Johnson's speakership, in a bid to avoid a replay of the chaos that occurred in October when Republicans ousted his predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nGreene's move represented a rare Republican defiance of presidential candidate Donald Trump, who in a social media post following the House vote on Wednesday, said it was \"not the time\" for Republicans to try to push out their own speaker.\n\nGreene's measure, known as a motion to vacate, showcased the disorder that has marked Republicans' slim 217-213 House majority, particularly since it had been clear that the effort would fail given Democrats' opposition.\n\n\"I appreciate the show of confidence from my colleagues to defeat this misguided effort,\" Johnson, 52, said following the vote. \"Hopefully this is the end of the character assassination that has characterized the current Congress.\"\n\nMultiple Republicans criticized Greene's move, including centrist Representative Marc Molinaro.\n\n\"This is not an individual who knows how to lead,\" Molinaro said of Greene. \"She's not an individual who knows how to negotiate. And she certainly doesn't seem to have any concern for the stability of the Congress or the people we represent.\"\n\nGreene stood flanked by fellow Republican Thomas Massie when she made her move against Johnson, criticizing him for a string of compromises with Democrats, who hold a majority in the Senate.\n\n\"Excuses like 'this is just how you have to govern in divided government' are pathetic, weak and unacceptable,\" Greene said of Johnson. \"Even with our razor-thin Republican majority we could have at least secured the border.\"\n\nTaunts and jeers\n\nThe chamber erupted in taunts and cheers at points as Greene read her resolution, with Democrats at times chanting \"Hakeem, Hakeem,\" a reference to their party leader, Hakeem Jeffries, in an echo of the many times they voted for him as speaker during Republicans' multiple rounds of voting for speaker since the current House was seated in January 2021.\n\nJohnson has angered many hard-liners by enacting bipartisan spending measures to avoid government shutdowns and aid US allies including Ukraine, without insisting on strict security measures for the US-Mexico border that Democrats reject.\n\nThe House Republicans' border security bill had no chance of passing the Democratic-controlled Senate.\n\nA bipartisan compromise bill negotiated late last year and early this year in the Senate, with the Biden administration's approval, was killed by House and Senate Republicans at Trump's behest.\n\nJohnson could be seen walking around the House floor after Greene began her call on Wednesday for his ouster, with Republican supporters shaking his hand and patting him on the back.\n\n\"Republicans have to be fighting the Radical Left Democrats, and all the Damage they have done to our Country,\" Trump said in his Wednesday post. \"We're not in a position of voting on a Motion to Vacate. At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time.\"\n\nThe situation has bolstered Jeffries, who agreed to save Johnson from ouster after freeing Congress from the road block of Republican infighting by delivering crucial Democratic support for must-pass bills.\n\nGreene in remarks to reporters after the vote did not rule out trying to oust Johnson again.\n\nFor his part, Jeffries said he hoped to see House Republicans turn against party hard-liners, saying, \"The only thing we ask of our House Republican colleagues is for traditional Republicans to further isolate the extreme MAGA Republican wing of the GOP, which has visited nothing but chaos and dysfunction on the American people.\"", "source": {"uri": "arab.news", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arab News"}, "authors": [], Marjorie Taylor Greene's resolution to oust Speaker Mike Johnson from his leadership post.\n\nThe vote on a motion to table succeeded with the help of Democrats, sparing Johnson from losing the speakership. The vote was 359 to 43.\n\nIn the wake of Johnson's push to pass a major foreign aid package over the objections of hardline conservatives, House Democratic leadership announced that Democrats would help Johnson keep his job by voting to table.\n\nGreene and Johnson - as well as Republican Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky - met over several days earlier this week, where Greene outlined her concerns with Johnson's leadership and her priorities. The House was on the verge of recessing for the week when Greene pulled up her motion to vacate the chair, which started a two-legislative-day clock for GOP leaders to hold a vote on her measure.\n\nHouse Republicans were completely caught off guard by Greene's decision to trigger her motion, multiple Republican sources told CNN. GOP leadership did not see this coming and thought after the two productive meetings between Johnson and Greene that there was at least more time before any next steps were taken, the sources added.\n\n\"I was shocked,\" GOP Rep. {"uri": "8119524633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:06:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:06:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:05:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/johnson-says-hes-willing-to-move-on-after-failed-ouster-attempt-5646987", "title": "Johnson Says He's Willing to Move on After Failed Ouster Attempt", "body": "The House on May 8 overwhelmingly rejected Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's push to vacate Mr. Johnson in a 359-43 vote.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) suggested that he's willing to move on from his disagreements with Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) after the Georgia Republican failed in her motion to vacate the speaker's chair.\n\nBut even though the measure was defeated, it raises alarm bells for Mr. Johnson's future leadership. Eleven Republicans voted to move forward on the motion -- three more than the number who voted to oust House Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) in October.\n\nNevertheless, Mr. Johnson said he's ready to move on from the issue, and hopes he can work with Ms. Greene in the future.\n\n\"I told her last night before we left the floor, 'Let's move on Marjorie. I'm okay with this. Let's move on.\"\n\nAsked how Ms. Greene replied, Mr. Johnson said only, \"I think we'll have an opportunity to do that. We'll see.\"\n\nMs. Greene, for her part, declined to answer a question after the vote on if she would bring the measure up to the floor again later in the Congress.\n\nBut former President Donald Trump, a close ally of Ms. Greene, indicated ahead of the vote on May 8 that he thinks now is \"not the time\" to pursue a motion to vacate against Mr. Johnson.\n\nSpeaking on the broader issue of the motion to vacate, Mr. Johnson called it \"unfortunate\" that the measure was brought to the floor in the first place.\n\n\"I appreciate the overwhelming show of confidence by my colleagues to defeat that misguided effort,\" Mr. Johnson said.\n\nHe also defended himself against allegations made by Ms. Greene about his conduct on a series of recent issues, citing Republicans' slim majority as the reason that conservatives couldn't get as many wins as they'd like.\n\n\"We advance our conservative policies and principles as far as we can here every single day ... in spite of the fact that we have the smallest majority in U.S. history,\" Mr. Johnson said. \"We can't get 100 percent of what we want. And sometimes a handful of my colleagues demand that.\n\n\"It's just not possible right now, but we're fighting.\"\n\nMr. Johnson was also asked about Democrats' help in bailing him out.\n\nThirty-two of the 43 votes in favor of moving forward on the motion came from Democrats, but this represents a small fraction of the Democratic caucus. The overwhelming majority of Democrats voted to prop up Mr. Johnson's speakership -- a fact that distinguishes him from Mr. McCarthy, who received no Democratic support.\n\nAsked why Democrats helped save him, Mr. Johnson replied, \"I think the Democrats believe in the institution and they see exactly what we see, and the American people see: these are dangerous times.\"\n\nHe added, \"The country desperately needs a functioning Congress. We can't afford the risk of shutting the House down.\"\n\nMr. Johnson warned of the disastrous consequences that could result from such a move if China decided to invade Taiwan or Iran fired a nuclear weapon at Israel.\n\n\"We need to be working here everyday,\" he said. \"The chaos and confusion do nothing but diminish our chances to save this country and hurt our cause.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8119199231", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:13:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:13:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:13:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.lgbtqnation.com/2024/05/humiliated-marjorie-taylor-greene-booed-on-house-floor-as-her-motion-to-vacate-mike-johnson-fails/", "title": "Humiliated: Marjorie Taylor Greene booed on House floor as her motion to vacate Mike Johnson fails", "body": "Transphobic Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) finally filed her motion to kick out House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) on Wednesday evening. A majority of her House Republican colleagues united with 163 Democrats to help defeat her motion immediately in a 359-43 vote, but not before booing her as she introduced the vote.\n\nBoos erupted on both sides of the House chamber as Greene read her resolution, The Hill reported. After defeating her motion, the chamber's members cheered. Even former President Donald Trump, who Greene deeply admires, said that now is \"not the time\" to kick out the speaker because it \"will be portrayed as chaos\" and negatively affect\" Republicans's chances during an election year.\n\n\"I appreciate the show of confidence from my colleagues to defeat this misguided effort,\" Johnson said after surviving the vote. \"That is certainly what it was.\"\n\nSubscribe to our briefing for insights into how politics impacts the LGBTQ+ community and more.\n\nGreene filed her initial motion to oust the speaker over a month ago. But as soon as she formally introduced it on Wednesday evening, House Majority Leader Steve Scalise (R-LA) immediately motioned to table her measure, setting up the vote that killed it.\n\nAfter the vote, Democrats noted that their votes weren't an endorsement of Johnson -- an anti-LGBTQ+ Christian nationalist who helped devise Trump's plan to overturn the 2020 election -- but rather a recognition of his successful compromises and willingness to allow votes on must-pass appropriations bills.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the House of Representatives and the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems for everyday Americans in a bipartisan manner,\" House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY) said after the vote. \"We need more commonsense and less chaos in Washington, D.C.\"\n\nGreene filed a surprise motion to oust Johnson because he allowed the House to vote on a $1.2 trillion government funding bill today that included funding for \"trans ideology,\" as she put it. The bill, which largely excluded her and other far-right Republicans' desired anti-LGBTQ+ provisions, cleared the House on March 22 in a 286 -134 vote.\n\nFar-right Reps. Thomas Massie (R-KY) and Paul Gosar (R-AZ) both pledged to support Greene's effort to kick out Johnson, but they were the only Republicans to do so.\n\nEarlier in the week, Greene met with Johnson in an attempt to get him to agree to four conditions to avoid her ouster vote: only bringing bills to a floor vote if they have support from a majority of the GOP conference (something known as the Hastert rule), not passing any additional aid for Ukraine, defunding special counsel investigations against Trump, and cutting national spending by 1%. Johnson didn't agree to any of her conditions.\n\nSenate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said he was happy to hear that Democrats and Republicans were uniting to defeat Greene. \"I'm relieved as I think all of America is that the chaos in the House will be discontinued,\" he said. \"I think it's a benefit to our country, a benefit to the House, a benefit to the reputation of Congress.\"\n\nRep. Clay Higgins (R-LA) called her move a \"mistake,\" adding, \"To think that one of our Republican colleagues would call for his ouster right now -- it's really, it's abhorrent to me, and I oppose it.\"\n\nRep. Mike Lawler (R-NY) said, \"It's not only idiotic, but it actually does not do anything to advance the conservative movement. And in fact, it undermines the country and our majority.\"", "source": {"uri": "lgbtqnation.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LGBTQ Nation"}, "authors": [{"uri": "daniel_villarreal@lgbtqnation.com", {"uri": "2024-05-349585601", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:23:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:23:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:23:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://eu.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2024/05/08/wisconsin-republicans-unite-in-blocking-ouster-of-speaker-mike-johnson/73591772007/", "title": "Wisconsin's House Republicans unite in blocking ouster of Speaker Mike Johnson", "body": "Reps. Marjorie Taylor Greene and Thomas Massie announced plans to oust Republican speaker.\n\nWASHINGTON - Wisconsin's House Republicans say they are tired with interparty fighting and threats from some on the far-right to remove Speaker Mike Johnson.\n\nRep. Scott Fitzgerald told the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel that the Republican conference is still feeling the effects of former Rep. Kevin McCarthy's ouster from the speakership last October. Rep. Derrick Van Orden has confronted critics of Johnson on the House floor. And Glenn Grothman indicated that removing another House speaker would be \"damaging\" to the party.\n\nAsked this week about Georgia Republican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's threats to force a vote to oust Johnson, Janesville Republican Rep. Bryan Steil said only: \"The whole thing is unproductive.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, all five Wisconsin Republicans voted to kill Greene's motion to remove the speaker after she forced a vote on the floor. Just 11 Republicans and 32 Democrats voted to move forward with a vote to oust Johnson, and the motion was ultimately killed on a 359-43 vote.\n\nThe vote put an end to weeks of public threats from Greene and Republican Reps. Thomas Massie of Kentucky and Paul Gosar of Arizona to force a vote to oust Johnson after the speaker helped pass bills funding the government. It also came nearly three weeks after the House passed a $95 billion foreign aid package that included support for Ukraine -- something Greene and others on the GOP's right flank oppose.\n\nJohnson on Wednesday relied on Democrats to save his job as Republicans hold just a one-vote majority in the House. One hundred sixty-three Democrats moved to kill the measure along with 196 Republicans, though Wisconsin's two House Democrats were wary of aiding the rescue.\n\n\"It's their problem,\" Rep. Mark Pocan, who voted \"present\" on the motion to kill the ouster attempt, told the Journal Sentinel this week before the vote. \"They keep having this internal problem because they made the rules. So either I say something is credible about Marjorie Taylor Greene, or I say something is credible about the most homophobic speaker we've ever elected.\"\n\n\"This is just their internal dysfunction,\" he added. \"I'm not part of that caucus, so I shouldn't have to deal with it.\"\n\nRep. Gwen Moore, a Milwaukee Democrat, voted with the majority of the chamber to table the motion. But she suggested earlier in the week that she was not eager to do so.\n\n\"There's no reason, other than to stop the chaos, to vote for Mike Johnson,\" she told the Journal Sentinel. \"He doesn't share the values that I share. There's no logical reason for me to vote for him for speaker. But at the same time, I want this place to run.\"\n\nGreene's attempt to oust Johnson came after she and Massie held several hours-long meetings with the speaker in the Capitol this week. The Georgia Republican gave Johnson a list of demands she wanted met to back off her threats, including that Congress provide no additional funding to Ukraine, move to defund any Justice Department investigations into former President Donald Trump and only put bills on the floor that a majority of Republicans support.\n\nOn Wednesday evening, she called the House to act on her motion to loud boos from her colleagues. \"This is the uni-party for the American people watching,\" she said to jeers in the chamber.\n\nWisconsin's Republicans, meanwhile, have been behind Johnson since he was elected the chamber's leader last year after three weeks of gridlock as Republicans struggled to replace McCarthy, who himself was ousted by a group of far-right Republicans under similar circumstances.\n\n\"I think among the Republican base, Mike is popular and you don't get points in your district for saying I want to kick out Mike,\" Grothman, a Republican from Glenbeulah, told the Journal Sentinel this week. \"Which is why so many of the people you would expect to pile on... they're not piling on, which tells you something.\"\n\nRep. Tom Tiffany said he didn't think it was a \"good approach\" to try to remove Johnson, noting he didn't support ousting McCarthy last October.\n\nOther members have suggested the frequent Republican infighting has hampered the chamber's abilities to get things done.\n\n\"That was three weeks of turmoil that we didn't need,\" Fitzgerald, a Juneau Republican, told the Journal Sentinel last month, referencing McCarthy's ouster. \"It set us back, I think, and we're still recovering from it.\"", "source": {"uri": "jsonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Journal Sentinel"}, "authors": [], Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, but chaos lingers", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Hardline Republican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene has tried and failed to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson. But the resounding rejection by Democrats and Republicans does not end the political chaos. One of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, Greene stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest, and Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise quickly countered by calling for a vote to table Greene's motion. An overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now. {"uri": "8118267124", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:02:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:02:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:01:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/house-speaker-mike-johnson-survives-005055267.html", "title": "House Speaker Mike Johnson survives effort to oust him from leadership", "body": "May 8 (UPI) -- House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., survived a motion to vacate filed by Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., by a 359-43-7 floor vote Wednesday.\n\nThe final vote effectively quashed Greene's motion to vacate by tabling it and was widely anticipated as majorities of House Republicans and Democrats opposed the effort to remove Johnson as House Speaker.\n\n\"Hopefully, this is the end of the personality politics and the frivolous character assassination that has defined the 118th Congress,\" Johnson said after surviving Greene's ouster motion, Politico reported.\n\nGreene and 10 other House Republicans voted against tabling her motion for Johnson to vacate the speaker position, as did 32 House Democrats.\n\n\"The motion to vacate attempt was only a headline-grabbing, petty political stunt to distract from our duties and raise money,\" Rep. Steve Womack, R-Ark., posted on X. \"I'm glad rationality overwhelmingly prevailed.\"\n\nFormer President Donald Trump, the presumptive GOP nominee for president, in a Truth Social post complimented Greene for having \"spirit\" but said \"Republicans have to be fighting the radical-left Democrats and all the damage they have done to our country,\" The Hill reported.\n\nTrump said now is the time for Republicans to show unity with the general election just six months away, and Trump leading President Joe Biden in several swing-state polls as well as nationally.\n\nWith Greene's motion tabled, it would take a majority in the House to vote to return it to the floor for consideration.\n\nTabling Greene's motion enabled Johnson to survive a similar fate suffered by former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., who last year was removed as Speaker when a motion to vacate filed by Rep. Matt Gaetz was approved.\n\nMcCarthy resigned from the House of Representatives on Dec. 31.\n\nGreene and Gaetz are members of the GOP House Freedom Caucus and said McCarthy and Johnson were not doing enough to advance conservative causes and viewpoints while working with Democrats to get legislation approved.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, {"uri": "8118675746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:32:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:32:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:31:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2024/05/09/3082504/republican-initiates-ouster-of-us-house-speaker", "title": "Republican Initiates Ouster of US House Speaker - Other Media news - Tasnim News Agency", "body": "TEHRAN (Tasnim) - Congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia has filed a motion to vacate the chair of the US House of Representatives, accusing Speaker Mike Johnson of Louisiana of betraying his party.\n\nAccording to the text of the resolution, made public by fellow Republican Thomas Massie of Kentucky, Johnson \"has not lived up to a single one\" of the seven tenets he announced when he was elected speaker last October, RT reported.\n\nJohnson's tenure \"is defined by one self-serving characteristic: When given a choice between advancing Republican priorities or allying with Democrats to preserve his own personal power, Johnson regularly chooses to ally himself with Democrats,\" Greene said.\n\nThe House leadership responded to Greene's proposal with a motion to dismiss the resolution. The final vote was 359 in favor (196 Republicans and 163 Democrats) to 43 opposed, saving Johnson's speakership.\n\nOnly 11 Republicans and 32 Democrats voted to support Greene's resolution, indirectly proving Greene's point that the speaker is aligned with the \"uniparty\" in Washington.\n\nAmong the things Greene and Massie - who backed her proposal - blamed Johnson for was the expulsion of Congressman George Santos in December. His seat was taken over by a Democrat in a special election. Johnson counted on Democrats to pass the omnibus government funding bill in March and the $61 billion funding package for Ukraine in April; on both occasions, the majority of House Republicans voted against.\n\n\"By passing the Democrats' agenda and handcuffing Republicans' ability to influence legislation, our elected Republican Speaker Mike Johnson has aided and abetted the Democrats and the Biden administration in destroying our country,\" Greene added.\n\nBills that Johnson worked to pass funded all of President Joe Biden and the Democrats' agenda, Greene argued, including the \"deadly border invasion,\" the \"energy-killing Green New Deal climate agenda,\" the \"weaponized\" FBI and the Department of Justice, the \"trans agenda on kids,\" continued full term abortions, and the \"fueling of foreign forever wars.\"\n\nGreene's resolution called Johnson's excuses for these actions \"pathetic, weak, and unacceptable,\" noting that even with a razor-thin majority in the House, the GOP still has the power of the purse.\n\nJohnson also trampled his previous record as a defender of civil liberties to vote against requiring a warrant for FISA spying on Americans, Greene said, {"uri": "8118346193", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:37:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:37:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:36:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://100percentfedup.com/house-overwhelmingly-backs-mike-johnson-effort-remove-speaker/", "title": "House Overwhelmingly Backs Mike Johnson In Effort To Remove Speaker, Donald Trump Issues Statement * 100PercentFedUp.com * by Danielle", "body": "The House of Representatives blocked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's (R-GA) effort to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson from his position.\n\nIn a 359-43 vote, the chamber tabled a motion to vacate the chair.\n\n196 Republicans and 163 Democrats voted to block the effort to oust Johnson from the speakership.\n\n11 Republicans and 32 Democrats voted to remove Johnson.\n\nThe House floor booed Greene as she introduced the motion to vacate the chair.\n\n\"This is the uniparty for the American people watching,\" Greene said.\n\n\"I appreciate the show of confidence from my colleagues to defeat this misguided effort,\" Johnson said, according to NBC News.\n\n\"Hopefully, this is the end of the personality politics and the frivolous character assassination that has defined the 118th Congress. It's regrettable. It's not who we are as Americans, and we're better than this. We need to get beyond it,\" he added.\n\nPer NBC News:\n\nGreene, who had threatened for weeks to force the issue, dragged her feet as it became clear she didn't have enough support to remove Johnson. Unlike in last year's successful vote to remove former Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., many Democrats had made it clear they would vote to save Johnson, especially after he helped stave off a government shutdown, pushed through the renewal of a critical intelligence surveillance spy tool and passed billions of dollars in foreign aid for Ukraine after months of delays.\n\nDuring the last vote series of the week, Greene stood on the floor and announced she was filing a privileged motion to vacate the speaker's chair. Colleagues promptly booed her.\n\n\"It's a new paradigm in Congress. Nancy Pelosi, and most republicans voted to keep Uniparty Speaker Mike Johnson. These are the eleven, including myself, who voted NOT to save him,\" Rep. Thomas Massie (R-KY) said.\n\n\"Vacating Kevin McCarthy was a huge mistake. Every Democrat voted to vacate him because he fought them tooth and nail. Keeping Mike Johnson is an even bigger mistake. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.).\n\nRep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) forced a vote on a motion to vacate after meeting with the speaker twice this week to discuss her grievances and demands.\n\nHouse Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) then offered a measure to table Ms. Greene's motion to vacate. Democrats joined Republicans to approve its shelving in a 359 to 43 vote. 11 Republicans voted to move forward with the ouster attempt.\n\nHouse Democrat leaders had earlier pledged to help protect Mr. Johnson in the event of Ms. Greene's ouster vote, citing his help in passing $95 billion foreign aid for Ukraine, Israel, and the Indo-Pacific.\n\nSpeaking on the House floor during what was intended to be the final vote of the week, Ms. Greene unleashed a litany of complaints against Mr. Johnson.\n\nShe received a loud \"boo\" from members present when she brought the resolution to the floor.\n\nThe Georgia lawmaker was accompanied by Rep. Thomas Massie (R-Ky.), one of two Republicans who openly expressed support for the measure.\n\nMr. Johnson has previously denounced Ms. Greene's attempt to oust him, calling it a \"dangerous gambit.\"\n\n\"I think it's wrong for the Republican Party. I think it's wrong for the institution,\" he said last week.\n\nMs. Greene, on the House floor, cited a series of alleged conservative failures by Mr. Johnson, alleging that he had \"aided and abetted the Biden administration in destroying our country.\"\n\nThese included his move to allow a vote on a motion to expel Rep. George Santos (R-N.Y.) from the lower chamber, marking the first time in U.S. history that a member has been expelled before a conviction for a crime.\n\nMs. Greene also cited his move to pass a 1,000-page, $1.2 trillion government funding package after giving lawmakers less than 48 hours to consider it, as required by internal rules.\n\nThe Georgia Republican also noted that Mr. Johnson's move to pass billions in foreign aid for Ukraine came without any demands on border security, effectively yielding any leverage Republicans had over the issue.\n\nAdditionally, she noted Mr. Johnson's {"uri": "2024-05-349530076", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:46:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:46:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:35:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13397667/Republican-firebrand-forces-vote-ousting-US-House-speaker.html", "title": "Republican firebrand forces vote on ousting US House speaker", "body": "US Republican Representatives Marjorie Taylor Greene (C), holds a press conference on House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries' (L in photo) endorsement of Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson (R in photo), outside the US Capitol in Washington, DC, on May 1, 2024\n\nA right-wing rebel lawmaker moved Wednesday to topple the Republican leader of the US House of Representatives in a vote that will likely fail -- but could mire the already-divided party in fresh conflict ahead of November's elections.\n\nUnder House rules, any single lawmaker can force a vote to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, and Georgia conservative Marjorie Taylor Greene finally pulled the trigger, more than six weeks after filing a \"motion to vacate\" his spot atop the Republican majority.\n\nBut Greene's effort has failed to gain traction among her colleagues and, crucially, is not supported by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, who recently said the speaker was \"doing a very good job.\"\n\nGreene is even opposed by Democratic leaders, ensuring the effort is almost certain to fall flat when it comes to the floor. House rules require a vote within 48 hours, although the leadership could move to dismiss the resolution within hours.\n\nGreene, a Trump ally, has two public supporters but none of the broader backing on the right that prompted the removal last year of Johnson's predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nShe is vowing to plow ahead anyway, as she seeks to make Republicans go on the record about whether they support Johnson.\n\nMany right-wing lawmakers are upset with the speaker for relying on Democratic votes to pursue an agenda they see as a betrayal of their conservative outlook on issues from Ukraine aid to government funding.\n\n\"No Republican speaker should ever share power with the Democrats. American voters gave Republicans in the House the majority for a reason... Mike Johnson must resign or be removed,\" Greene posted on X on Friday.\n\nBut rank-and-file lawmakers are wary of repeating the chaos of McCarthy's removal in a right-wing rebellion that left the House paralyzed for three weeks as they struggled to find a replacement, before finally settling on Johnson.\n\nAnd with the presidential and congressional elections less than six months away, Republicans see threatening Johnson's gavel as divisive and damaging to their prospects of unified control in Washington.\n\nThe voting tally is sure to be scrutinized for what it suggests about Johnson's viability as a Republican leader after November.\n\nSome allies of the speaker fear that his rescue by Democrats could make his position untenable in the long term, although the scale of the pushback against Greene may have stilled their nerves.\n\n\"She's pretty much operating on her own, with one or two others who have expressed support for what she's doing,\" Bob Good, chairman of the hard-right House Freedom Caucus, told cable network NewsNation on Sunday.\n\nJohnson condemned the move in an interview on SiriusXM's \"The Laura Coates Show\" on Friday.\n\n\"I think it's wrong for the Republican Party, I think it's wrong for the institution, I think it's wrong for the country,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) is moving forward with a vote on whether to remove Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) from his position. The move elicited loud boos from her colleagues.\n\nGreene filed a motion to vacate the chair in March, which would have entitled her to call for a vote of the House on whether to remove Johnson. Although the Georgia lawmaker declined to move forward at the time, on Tuesday she called for a vote.\n\nThe resolution is as follows,\" she said on the House floor. \"Declaring the office of speaker of the House of Representatives to be vacant-\"\n\nGreene was interrupted by a loud chorus of boos.\n\n\"Boooooo!\" shouted several lawmakers in unison. \"Boooooo!'\n\n\"This is the uniparty, for the American people watching,\" she said, referring to her detractors.\n\nHer comment prompted more boos.\n\n\"Speaker Johnson has not lived up to a single one of his self-approved tenets,\" she claimed. Greene has criticized Johnson for shepherding through several short-term government funding bills and for approving foreign aid packages, including aid to Ukraine, which Greene has long opposed.\n\nThe lawmaker's effort has garnered criticism from her fellow Republicans.\n\n\"She needs her time in the spotlight, you know, and it's been a while, and I think it's one last ditch effort to get attention, is what she's looking for,\" said Rep. Dan Crenshaw (R-TX). Meanwhile, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-RX) called Greene's effort to oust Johnson \"silly.\"\n\nCurrent House rules allow a single member to file a motion to vacate and trigger a vote of the full House on removing the speaker. In October, Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL) filed such a motion, which ultimately led to the removal of then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-CA). Just eight Republicans voted to remove McCarthy, but that was sufficient because all Democrats voted to oust him as well. Johnson", "body": "The US House of Representatives has quickly defeated an effort by firebrand Republican Marjorie Taylor Greene to remove fellow Republican Speaker Mike Johnson from his leadership role.\n\nDemocrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote on Wednesday to protect Johnson's speakership, in a bid to avoid a replay of the chaos that followed in October when Republicans ousted his predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nGreene's move represented a rare Republican defiance of presidential candidate Donald Trump, who had voiced support for Johnson and called the drive to oust him \"unfortunate\".\n\nStanding flanked by fellow Republican Thomas Massie, Greene criticised Johnson for a string of compromises with Democrats, who hold a majority in the Senate.\n\n\"Excuses like 'this is just how you have to govern in divided government' are pathetic, weak and unacceptable,\" Greene said of Johnson. \"Even with our razor-thin Republican majority we could have at least secured the border.\"\n\nBut the chamber erupted in taunts and cheers at points as Greene read her resolution, with Democrats at times chanting \"Hakeem, Hakeem\", a reference to their party leader Hakeem Jeffries, in an echo of the many times they voted for him as Speaker during Republicans' multiple rounds of voting for Speaker since the current House was seated in January 2021.\n\nJohnson has angered many hardliners within his razor-thin 217-213 Republican majority in 2024, by enacting bipartisan spending measures to avoid government shutdowns and aid US allies including Ukraine, without insisting on strict security measures for the US-Mexico border that Democrats reject.\n\nJohnson could be seen walking around the House floor after Greene began her call on Wednesday for his ouster, with Republican supporters shaking his hand and patting him on the back.\n\nThe situation has bolstered Jeffries, who agreed to save Johnson from ouster after freeing Congress from the roadblock of Republican infighting by delivering crucial Democratic support for must-pass bills.\n\nGreene's bid to seek retribution by unseating the speaker with a \"motion to vacate\" won support from only two {"uri": "8118273614", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:11:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:11:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:09:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/republican-firebrand-forces-vote-ousting-213102141.html", "title": "Democrats save Republican US House speaker from right-wing rebel", "body": "Democrats voted to rescue the Republican leader of the US House of Representatives on Wednesday after a right-wing lawmaker moved to topple him, plunging the already-divided party into fresh conflict ahead of November's elections.\n\nUnder House rules, any single lawmaker can force a vote to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, and Marjorie Taylor Greene finally pulled the trigger more than six weeks after filing a \"motion to vacate\" his position atop the Republican majority.\n\nThe Georgia conservative was booed by colleagues as she formally announced the effort on the House floor, reeling off a litany of grievances over Johnson's leadership.\n\nShe accused the speaker of \"regularly\" siding with Democrats to consolidate power and of running a party that \"fuels foreign wars, tramples on civil liberties and increases our disastrous national debt.\"\n\nBut Greene had failed to gain traction among her colleagues and, crucially, she was not supported by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, who recently said the speaker was \"doing a very good job.\"\n\nGreene was also opposed by the Democratic leadership, and it was never in doubt that the effort would fall flat. In the end 163 Democrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote to dismiss the resolution.\n\nGreene, a fervent Trump ally, had two public supporters but none of the broader backing on the right that prompted the removal last year of Johnson's predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nShe plowed ahead anyway, seeking to make Republicans go on the record about whether they support Johnson.\n\nMany right-wing lawmakers are upset with the speaker for relying on Democratic votes to pursue an agenda they see as a betrayal of their conservative outlook on issues from Ukraine aid to government funding.\n\nBut rank-and-file lawmakers in both parties were wary of repeating the chaos of McCarthy's removal, which left the House paralyzed for three weeks as they struggled to find a replacement.\n\nAnd with the presidential and congressional elections less than six months away, Republicans see threatening Johnson's gavel as divisive and damaging to their prospects of unified control in Washington.\n\nTrump praised Greene in an effusive statement released on his Truth Social platform after the vote.\n\n\"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene. She's got Spirit, she's got Fight, and I believe she'll be around, and on our side, for a long time to come,\" he said.\n\nBut he added that Republicans were \"not in a position\" to oust Johnson.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" he said.\n\nAfter the vote Johnson said: \"I want to say that I appreciate the show of confidence from my colleagues to {"uri": "2024-05-350451735", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:07:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:07:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:37:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/9/mike-johnson-says-he-holds-no-grudge-against-marjo/", "title": "Speaker Johnson says he holds no grudge against MTG over vacate move", "body": "House Speaker Mike Johnson said he just wants to move on from Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's \"unfortunate\" motion to oust him.\n\n\"I don't hold grudges. I've got to work with everybody. I told her last night before she left the floor, 'Let's move on, Marjorie. I'm OK with this. Let's move on,'\" Mr. Johnson said on \"Fox & Friends\" Thursday.\n\nMs. Greene, Georgia Republican, shocked many Wednesday when she brought up the motion to vacate after threatening Mr. Johnson, Louisiana Republican, with it for weeks. Her effort was short-lived, with the vote 359-43 to table to motion.\n\nWhen asked if he considers Ms. Greene a \"serious legislator,\" Mr. Johnson said it's not his place to decide.\n\n\"Look, I'm going to let other people judge Marjorie,\" he said. \"I've got to work with all my colleagues here. I'm not mad at anybody.\"\n\nMs. Greene originally brought up the motion to vacate after the speaker worked with Democrats to pass a bipartisan government funding bill to stop a government shutdown. Republicans, including former President Donald Trump and his team, have been telling her to let it go.\n\nShe has ripped Mr. Johnson as \"the uniparty speaker of the House\" that \"didn't stop the border crisis, didn't stop funding foreign wars, didn't protect America's energy industry, didn't cut spending to reduce inflation, didn't defund the weaponized government.\"\n\nMr. Johnson said despite what House conservatives want, not everything can get done with their slim majority.\n\n\"We advance our conservative policies and principles as far as we can here every single day up the field, in spite the fact that we have the smallest majority in U.S. history,\" he said. \"We can't get 100% of what we want, and sometimes a handful of my colleagues demand that. It's just not possible right now.\"\n\nThe motion to vacate was tabled with the help of 163 Democrats. Former Rep. Kevin McCarthy didn't enjoy the same luxury of Democrats' help when he was ousted in October. Mr. Johnson said he thinks he got the help because Democrats \"believe in the institution and they see exactly what we see and the American people see.\"\n\n\"These are dangerous times,\" he said. \"And the country desperately needs a functioning Congress. {"uri": "8118550954", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "06:00:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T06:00:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:00:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/democrats-rescue-republican-us-house-speaker-1823049.html", "title": "Democrats Rescue Republican US House Speaker From Right Wing Rebellion - UrduPoint", "body": "Washington, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 9th May, 2024) Democrats voted to rescue the Republican leader of the US House of Representatives Wednesday after a right-wing lawmaker moved to topple him, plunging the already-divided party into fresh conflict ahead of November's elections.\n\nUnder House rules, any single lawmaker can force a vote to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, and Marjorie Taylor Greene finally pulled the trigger more than six weeks after filing a \"motion to vacate\" his spot atop the Republican majority.\n\nThe Georgia conservative was booed by colleagues as she formally announced the effort on the House floor, reeling off a litany of grievances over Johnson's leadership.\n\nShe accused the speaker of \"regularly\" siding with Democrats to consolidate power and of running a party that \"fuels foreign wars, tramples on civil liberties and increases our disastrous national debt.\"\n\nBut Greene had failed to gain traction among her colleagues and, crucially, she was not supported by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, who recently said the speaker was \"doing a very good job.\"\n\nGreene was also opposed by the Democratic leadership, and it was never in doubt that the effort would fall flat. In the end 163 Democrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote to dismiss the resolution.\n\nGreene, a fervent Trump ally, had two public supporters but none of the broader backing on the right that prompted the removal last year of Johnson's predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nShe plowed ahead anyway, seeking to make Republicans go on the record about whether they support Johnson.\n\nBut rank-and-file lawmakers in both parties were wary of repeating the chaos of McCarthy's removal in a right-wing rebellion that left the House paralyzed for three weeks as they struggled to find a replacement.\n\nAnd with the presidential and congressional elections less than six months away, Republicans see threatening Johnson's gavel as divisive and damaging to their prospects of unified control in Washington.\n\nTrump praised Greene in an effusive statement released on his Truth Social platform after the vote.\n\n\"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene. She's got Spirit, she's got Fight, and I believe she'll be around, and on our side, for a long time to come,\" he said.\n\nBut he added that Republicans were \"not in a position\" to oust Johnson.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" he said.\n\nThe voting tally is sure to be scrutinized for what it suggests about Johnson's viability as a Republican leader after November.\n\nSome allies of the speaker fear that his rescue by Democrats could make his position untenable in the long term, although the scale of the pushback against Greene may have stilled their nerves.\n\nJohnson condemned the move in an interview on SiriusXM's \"The Laura Coates Show\" on Friday.\n\n\"I think it's wrong for the Republican Party, I think it's wrong for the institution, I think it's wrong for the country,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UrduPoint"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
