{"uri": "8119190637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:08:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:08:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:08:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/maddowblog/fight-johnson-gops-greene-suffers-one-loss-rcna151415", "title": "In fight with Johnson, GOP's Greene suffers more than one loss", "body": "What does Republican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene have to show for her failed effort to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson? Less than nothing.\n\nAs 2024 got underway, amidst chatter that there were \"knives out\" for House Speaker Mike Johnson among members of his own party, Republicans such as Rep. Chip Roy of Texas floated the possibility of targeting the Louisianan with a motion to vacate the chair. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene acknowledged the intraparty talk -- but rejected it.\n\n\"I would say that Chip Roy haphazardly throwing in a motion to vacate is probably about the dumbest thing that could happen,\" the Georgian told The Hill exactly four months today, \"because I think the last motion to vacate was pretty stupid, and has thrown our conference into utter chaos.\" The right-wing congresswoman added, \"I'm kind of sick of the chaos.\"\n\nSoon after, Greene changed her mind, went in the opposite direction, and launched a crusade to bring down her own party's House speaker. In hindsight, she probably should've stuck to her original instinct. NBC News reported:\n\nThe last time the House voted on such an effort was in October, when eight Republicans turned against then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy. They were joined by House Democrats, and the result was a narrow 216-210 vote.\n\nGoing into this new showdown, everyone on both sides of the aisle knew that Greene's effort wouldn't be nearly as close, and it wasn't. A total of 11 House Republicans, including Greene, voted to proceed with the effort, while 196 GOP members rejected it. Among Democrats, 163 members of the House minority joined with Republicans to scuttle the scheme; 32 voted to advance it; and 7 Democrats voted \"present.\"\n\nWhat happens now? When it comes to the congressional process, nothing. Greene took her best shot; she failed spectacularly; and lawmakers will now go back to their previously scheduled plans. The Georgian could theoretically try again at some point, but it's unlikely that a second attempt would be any more successful than the first.\n\nBut that's not to say this gambit was inconsequential. On the contrary, when assessing what Greene has to show for her efforts, it's important to realize that she ended up with less than nothing: The radical congresswoman is much worse off than she was before. What's more, the congresswoman settled on a series of rather specific demands she expected GOP leaders to meet, but ended up receiving exactly zero concessions from Johnson and his team.\n\nTo be {"uri": "2024-05-349668130", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:18:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:18:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:04:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/republican-us-house-speaker-survives-020444468.html", "title": "Republican US House speaker survives right-wing rebel's attempt to oust him", "body": "Democrats voted to rescue the Republican leader of the US House of Representatives on Wednesday after a right-wing lawmaker moved to topple him, plunging the already-divided party into fresh conflict ahead of November's elections.\n\nUnder House rules, any single lawmaker can force a vote to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, and Marjorie Taylor Greene finally pulled the trigger more than six weeks after filing a \"motion to vacate\" his position atop the Republican majority.\n\nThe Georgia conservative was booed by colleagues as she formally announced the effort on the House floor, reeling off a litany of grievances over Johnson's leadership.\n\nShe accused the speaker of \"regularly\" siding with Democrats to consolidate power and of running a party that \"fuels foreign wars, tramples on civil liberties and increases our disastrous national debt.\"\n\nBut Greene had failed to gain traction among her colleagues and, crucially, she was not supported by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, who recently said the speaker was \"doing a very good job.\"\n\nGreene was also opposed by the Democratic leadership, and it was never in doubt that the effort would fall flat. In the end 163 Democrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote to dismiss the resolution.\n\nGreene, a fervent Trump ally, had two public supporters but none of the broader backing on the right that prompted the removal last year of Johnson's predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nShe plowed ahead anyway, seeking to make Republicans go on the record about whether they support Johnson.\n\n(AFP)", {"uri": "2024-05-350274013", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:18:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:18:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:14:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/house/4653325-greene-blasts-critics-of-motion-to-oust-speaker-johnson/", "title": "Greene blasts critics of motion to oust Speaker Johnson", "body": "Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-La.) on Thursday hit back at the critics of her effort to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.), arguing the forecasted \"scary bad things\" did not happen after the vote.\n\n\"All the scary bad things they all told you would happen if I called the motion to vacate didn't happen,\" Greene wrote in a post on X Thursday.\n\n\"They said 'Democrats would take control of the House and Jeffries would become Speaker because Republicans only have the majority with one seat,'\" she wrote. \"Didn't happen. Instead, Democrats voted to save Johnson because they knew it was impossible to take control of the House and they want to keep Johnson because he's given them everything they want.\"\n\nThe House on Wednesday voted to block an attempt led by Greene to boot Johnson from the Speakership. The final vote was 359-43-7, with 196 Republicans and 163 Democrats choosing to save Johnson.\n\nThere was little doubt on the result. Democrats had indicated they would provide the votes to help Johnson last week.\n\nRepublicans were broadly against Greene's motion, arguing it was a doomed and unnecessary distraction that put the spotlight on internal squabbles instead of problems they want to emphasize with the Biden administration ahead of the fall elections.\n\nGreene fired back at critics who argued the lower chamber should be focused on policy-based issues, writing, \"Doing things for the American people and focusing on serious issues didn't happen because the Uniparty reared it's ugly head and voted to protect their Uniparty leader and to keep the status quo which has done nothing to for the American people or solved problems on serious issues.\"\n\nThe \"Uniparty\" is Greene's insult of Democrats and Republicans who vote together on certain issues.\n\nJohnson's decision to bring various bills to the floor that ended up passing with Democratic support, such as measures to prevent a government shutdown and provide aid to Ukraine, spurred her decision on the motion to vacate.\n\nAt the end of her lengthy X post, Greene ripped Congress for what she argued was a lack of border security measures and the continued funding for global conflicts.\n\n\"Congress, which is paid by the American people and sent to represent them, didn't stop the border crisis, didn't stop funding foreign wars, didn't protect America's energy industry, didn't cut spending to reduce inflation, didn't defund the weaponized government, instead Congress protected itself and kept the Uniparty control over the People's House,\" she said.\n\nGreene and Johnson met for hours earlier this week, during which she listed a series of demands for the Speaker. Among these included only bringing bills to the floor that have the support from a majority of the GOP conference, vowing against additional aid for Ukraine, establishing a 1 percent spending cut across the board, and defunding special counsels, including Jack Smith, who is probing former President Trump.\n\nJohnson told reporters on Tuesday he was \"working through a lot of ideas and {"uri": "2024-05-349578902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:11:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:11:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:36:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.oneindia.com/india/house-rejects-greene-effort-remove-speaker-johnson-011-3820109.html", "title": "Bipartisan House Vote Swiftly Defeats Greene's Move Against Speaker Johnson", "body": "Bipartisan House Vote Swiftly Defeats Greene's Move Against Speaker Johnson\n\nIn a dramatic turn of events on Capitol Hill, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene's attempt to remove Speaker Mike Johnson from his position was swiftly defeated. The motion, seen as a long-shot by many, was met with overwhelming opposition, marking a significant moment in the ongoing political saga within the United States Congress.\n\nGreene, a staunch supporter of former President Donald Trump, took to the House floor to list what she described as Johnson's failures in leadership. Her criticisms were met with vocal disapproval from her colleagues, highlighting the deep divisions within the party. Despite her efforts, the motion to vacate Johnson was quickly countered by Republican Majority Leader Steve Scalise, who called for a vote to table Greene's proposal. The result was a resounding 359-43 vote in favor of keeping Johnson in his role.\n\nThis incident underscores the current state of turmoil within the Republican Party, marking the second attempt in recent months to oust their own speaker. Such moves are rare in U.S. political history and signal a party at odds with itself. In the face of this challenge, GOP lawmakers rallied around Johnson, offering him visible support on the House floor.\n\nJohnson's leadership has been under scrutiny, particularly regarding his stance on foreign aid. Greene had previously threatened to force a vote on his removal if he proceeded with a package that included funds for Ukraine -- a package that was ultimately passed and signed into law. Despite these tensions, Johnson remained steadfast, emphasizing the importance of supporting Ukraine against Russia's invasion and asserting his commitment to doing what he believes is right.\n\nIn an unexpected twist, Democrats, led by Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, came to Johnson's defense. Jeffries and his team advocated for moving beyond the GOP's internal conflicts to ensure the functionality of Congress. This bipartisan support was crucial in thwarting Greene's attempt to unseat Johnson.\n\nAdding another layer to this complex political drama, Trump expressed his affection for Greene but highlighted the need for Republicans to focus on defeating Democrats in the upcoming November election rather than engaging in internal disputes.\n\nThe vote not only demonstrated the support Johnson enjoys within his party but also exposed the challenges Greene faces as she navigates her role as a provocateur within the GOP. Her insistence on forcing her colleagues to publicly declare their stance put many in a difficult position but ultimately showed a desire within the party to move past internal strife and focus on broader political goals.\n\nLast year's attempt to remove Kevin McCarthy from the speaker's office resulted in a protracted search for new leadership -- a situation Republicans were keen to avoid this time around. This latest episode serves as a reminder of the delicate balance of power within Congress and the ongoing struggles within the Republican Party as it looks ahead to future elections.", "source": {"uri": "8118191721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:23:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:23:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:22:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/democrats-rescue-republican-us-house-speaker-from-right-wing-rebellion/article_2c44cba8-91e3-56d9-8f82-7da6b93c0957.html", "title": "Democrats rescue Republican US House speaker from right wing rebellion", "body": "Democrats voted to rescue the Republican leader of the US House of Representatives Wednesday after a right-wing lawmaker moved to topple him, plunging the already-divided party into fresh conflict ahead of November's elections.\n\nUnder House rules, any single lawmaker can force a vote to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, and Marjorie Taylor Greene finally pulled the trigger more than six weeks after filing a \"motion to vacate\" his spot atop the Republican majority.\n\nThe Georgia conservative was booed by colleagues as she formally announced the effort on the House floor, reeling off a litany of grievances over Johnson's leadership.\n\nShe accused the speaker of \"regularly\" siding with Democrats to consolidate power and of running a party that \"fuels foreign wars, tramples on civil liberties and increases our disastrous national debt.\"\n\nBut Greene had failed to gain traction among her colleagues and, crucially, she was not supported by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, who recently said the speaker was \"doing a very good job.\"\n\nGreene was also opposed by the Democratic leadership, and it was never in doubt that the effort would fall flat. In the end 163 Democrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote to dismiss the resolution.\n\nGreene, a fervent Trump ally, had two public supporters but none of the broader backing on the right that prompted the removal last year of Johnson's predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nShe plowed ahead anyway, seeking to make Republicans go on the record about whether they support Johnson.\n\nMany right-wing lawmakers are upset with the speaker for relying on Democratic votes to pursue an agenda they see as a betrayal of their conservative outlook on issues from Ukraine aid to government funding.\n\nBut rank-and-file lawmakers in both parties were wary of repeating the chaos of McCarthy's removal in a right-wing rebellion that left the House paralyzed for three weeks as they struggled to find a replacement.\n\nMore from this section 1st PWHL playoffs begin with Toronto hosting Minnesota Fitness in Four: Standing exercises to help improve your posture Trump's Trial Postponed Indefinitely By Judge Amid Pre-Trial Issues\n\nAnd with the presidential and congressional elections less than six months away, Republicans see threatening Johnson's gavel as divisive and damaging to their prospects of unified control in Washington.\n\nTrump praised Greene in an effusive statement released on his Truth Social platform after the vote.\n\n\"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene. She's got Spirit, she's got Fight, and I believe she'll be around, and on our side, for a long time to come,\" he said.\n\nBut he added that Republicans were \"not in a position\" to oust Johnson.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" he said.\n\nThe voting tally is sure to be scrutinized for what it suggests about Johnson's viability as a Republican leader after November.\n\nSome allies of the speaker fear that his rescue by Democrats could make his position untenable in the long term, although the scale of the pushback against Greene may have stilled their nerves.\n\nJohnson condemned the move in an interview on SiriusXM's \"The Laura Coates Show\" on Friday.\n\n\"I think it's wrong for the Republican Party, I think it's wrong for the In the end 163 Democrats joined Republicans in a 359-43 vote to dismiss the resolution.\n\nGreene, a fervent Trump ally, had two public supporters but none of the broader backing on the right that prompted the removal last year of Johnson's predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nShe plowed ahead anyway, seeking to make Republicans go on the record about whether they support Johnson.\n\nMany right-wing lawmakers are upset with the speaker for relying on Democratic votes to pursue an agenda they see as a betrayal of their conservative outlook on issues from Ukraine aid to government funding.\n\nBut rank-and-file lawmakers in both parties were wary of repeating the chaos of McCarthy's removal in a right-wing rebellion that left the House paralyzed for three weeks as they struggled to find a replacement.\n\nAnd with the presidential and congressional elections less than six months away, Republicans see threatening Johnson's gavel as divisive and damaging to their prospects of unified control in Washington.\n\nTrump praised Greene in an effusive statement released on his Truth Social platform after the vote.\n\n\"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene. Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia sought to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson from the speakership on Wednesday, but the move was soundly rejected, with most House Democrats joining with most House Republicans to put the kibosh on the ouster effort.\n\n\"The Uniparty has spoken, and Mike Johnson is their speaker,\" GOP Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky said in a statement to Blaze News.\n\nOverall, the vote was 359-43 in favor of tabling the motion to vacate, with seven voting present. While 196 Republicans and 163 Democrats joined together in the vote to table the matter, 11 Republicans and 32 Democrats opposed the motion to table.\n\n\"It's a new paradigm in Congress.\"\n\nThe 11 Republicans who opposed tabling the motion included Reps. Greene, Massie, Warren Davidson of Ohio, Alex Mooney of West Virginia, Barry Moore of Alabama; Victoria Spartz of Indiana. Chip Roy of Texas; Paul Gosar of Arizona, Eli Crane of Arizona, Eric Burlison of Missouri, and Andy Biggs of Arizona.\n\n-- (@)\n\n\"It's a new paradigm in Congress. Nancy Pelosi, and most republicans voted to keep Uniparty Speaker Mike Johnson. These are the eleven, including myself, who voted NOT to save him,\" Massie tweeted.\n\nLast week, House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York, Democratic Whip Katherine Clark of Massachusetts, and Democratic Caucus Chair Pete Aguilar of California had announced that if Greene sought to oust the speaker, they would vote to table the motion to vacate.\n\nIn a post on X, Massie shared what he said was the text of Greene's motion to vacate.\n\n\"Whereas, Speaker Johnson's tenure is defined by one self-serving characteristic: When given a choice between advancing Republican priorities or allying with Democrats to preserve his own personal power, Johnson regularly chooses to ally himself with Democrats,\" a portion of the text reads, according to Massie's post.\n\n-- {"uri": "2024-05-350517316", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:16:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:16:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:10:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://eu.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2024/05/09/why-marjorie-taylor-greene-motion-to-vacate-the-house-speaker-failed/73627239007/", "title": "Another speaker ouster attempt? Why Marjorie Taylor Greene's motion to vacate failed and Matt Gaetz's succeeded", "body": "Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene faced boos on the House floor in her efforts to oust Mike Johnson as Speaker of the House.\n\nFor the second time this congress, a far-right Republican attempted to oust the speaker of the United States House of Representatives. The first time was in October, when a Florida representative successfully led the effort to oust Kevin McCarthy from the speakership. He did so with the help of Knoxville's representative, Tim Burchett.\n\nThis time around, Georgia's Marjorie Taylor Greene led the same type of effort but received minimal support. Her attempt to oust current speaker Rep. Mike Johnson, a Louisiana Republican, failed miserably.\n\nGreene threatened to introduce her motion to vacate for weeks. She did so May 8 and 15 minutes later, a ranking member of her own party led the effort to kill the bill. That effort won 359 votes -- only 11 Republicans voted to save it.\n\nWhat's a motion to vacate?\n\nA motion to vacate is the procedural tool used to oust a Speaker of the House.\n\nThough previous speakers controlled how leaders could be removed, a recent rule change McCarthy agreed to upon becoming speaker allows any member of the House to file a motion to vacate and force the speaker out.\n\nThe motion only needs a simple majority of 218 votes to pass.\n\nThere have been five total attempts to remove a speaker in U.S. history, and McCarthy's ouster was the only successful one.\n\nWhy did it pass last time and fail this time?\n\nRep. Matt Gaetz introduced a motion to vacate the speakership due to McCarthy compromising on a stopgap funding bill to avert a shutdown of the federal government.\n\nGaetz and other House conservatives, including Burchett, had opposed the temporary funding measure. The Florida congressman accused McCarthy of lying to Republicans during funding negotiations and working with Democrats on the agreement.\n\nThe McCarthy ouster wouldn't have been successful without the support of Democrats.\n\nHouse Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., came out swinging when he explained why his caucus shouldn't come to McCarthy's rescue. In a lengthy letter to members, he cited the GOP's \"unwillingness to break from MAGA extremism\" as a chief reason.\n\nJeffries spent a good portion of his political capital on helping topple McCarthy, who failed to reach an agreement with House Democratic leaders on a way to save himself by establishing a bipartisan, coalition government.\n\nThis time around, the motion to vacate didn't have Democratic support.\n\nDemocrats joined the majority of Republicans to defeat Greene's effort after Johnson passed a long-awaited foreign aid package that sent $95 billion to key U.S. allies, including Ukraine. Democrats commended the speaker for not bowing to his hard-right flank, which has grown increasingly hostile toward any continued U.S. assistance to the war-torn nation.\n\n\"We will vote to table Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's Motion to Vacate the Chair. If she invokes the motion, it will not succeed,\" House Democratic leaders said in a statement last week.\n\nThe McCarthy ouster also wouldn't have been successful without the support of the \"Gaetz 8,\" the group of eight Republicans who voted to oust their fellow party member. Of that group, only two supported Greene's effort.\n\nOutside those two, only eight Republicans supported Greene's motion.\n\nHow did Tennessee representatives vote?\n\nTennessee's congressional delegation presented a unified front. Every single representative voted to kill Greene's motion to vacate.\n\nThat's a change from McCarthy's ouster, when Burchett voted to vacate.\n\nHe did so then because he said McCarthy refused to pass a federal budget that addresses overspending. But Burchett was supportive of Johnson after he followed in McCarthy's footsteps, passing a stopgap measure to keep the government open.\n\nBurchett reaffirmed that support by voting to kill Greene's motion to vacate May 8.\n\n\"When I voted to remove the previous speaker, I knew we would get a Republican to replace him,\" Burchett said in a statement. \"That is no longer the case. If we remove Speaker Johnson from his seat, we'll likely get a Democrat to replace him, or a more moderate Republican who is supported by Democrats.\"\n\nHe said he'll keep pushing Johnson, but couldn't vote to remove him knowing his replacement could be \"worse.\"\n\nCould Marjorie Taylor Greene try another motion to vacate?\n\nSure, it's always possible. But Greene didn't comment May 8 on whether she would try again.\n\nAnd the reactions to Greene's effort weren't favorable. It's clear from Republicans' reactions that anyone who brings a motion to vacate forward could face political backlash. Here's what some, have said, according to reporting from the Associated Press.\n\nUSA TODAY reporters Marina Pitofsky, Riley Beggin and Ken Tran contributed to this report.\n\nAllie Feinberg reports on politics for Knox News. Email her: allie.feinberg@knoxnewsws.com and follow her on X, formerly known as Twitter, @alliefeinberg.", "source": {"uri": "tennessean.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tennessean"}, {"uri": "8119096491", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:05:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:05:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:05:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.salon.com/2024/05/09/mtgs-bid-to-oust-maga-mike-johnson-badly-fails-as-democrats-derail-gop-chaos-caucus/", "title": "MTG's bid to oust \"MAGA Mike\" Johnson badly fails as Democrats derail \"GOP chaos caucus\"", "body": "The majority of Democrats and Republicans in the U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday saved far-right Speaker Mike Johnson from Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's attempt to oust him after less than seven months in the leadership position.\n\nJohnson's (R-La.) election to the role in October -- following the ouster of former Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.), who then left Congress early -- was seen as a signal of the MAGA flank's hold on the Republican Party. However, since then he has faced criticism from Greene (R-Ga.) and others for, among other things, not shutting down the government.\n\nGreene delivered on her threatened motion to vacate -- provoking boos from fellow lawmakers -- after meeting with Johnson for hours on Monday and Tuesday. The final vote to table her resolution was 359-43, with 196 Republicans and 163 Democrats backing the far-right speaker. Seven Democrats voted present and 21 lawmakers did not vote.\n\nTen Republicans joined Greene in trying to give Johnson the boot: Reps. Andy Biggs (Ariz.), Eric Burlison (Mo.), Eli Crane (Ariz.), Warren Davidson (Ohio), Paul Gosar (Ariz.), Thomas Massie (Ky.), Alex Mooney (W.Va.), Barry Moore (Ala.), Chip Roy (Texas), and Victoria Spartz (Ind.).\n\nAddressing the position of most Democrats, House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (N.Y.) said in a statement:\n\nOur decision to stop Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the House of Representatives and the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solving problems for everyday Americans in a bipartisan manner. We need more common sense and less chaos in Washington, D.C.\n\nMarjorie Taylor Greene and the extreme MAGA Republicans are chaos agents. House Democrats are change agents. We will continue to govern in a reasonable, responsible, and results-oriented manner and to put people over politics all day and every day.\n\nSome of the 32 Democrats who supported ousting Johnson framed the vote as proof that -- in the words of Rep. Maxwell Alejandro Frost (Fla.) -- the \"GOP really can't govern\" and the \"chaos caucus is on display.\"\n\nCongresswoman Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) similarly declared on social media that \"the GOP chaos caucus continues to do nothing for the American people and instead waste time infighting.\"\n\n\"Speaker Johnson organized an amicus brief effort to overturn the 2020 election. He opposes abortion rights, trans rights, and voting rights,\" Jayapal also said. \"That's why I did not vote to save his speakership.\"\n\nRep. Gerry Connolly (D-Va.) also explained his vote on social media, saying: \"Mike Johnson is the most ideological, right-wing speaker since the 1830s. His views and values are directly antithetical to mine. He stands for everything we, as freedom-loving Democrats, proudly stand against. I will never vote to keep him in that chair.\"\n\nCongressman Mark Pocan (D-Wis.) was one of the members who voted present, which does not count for or against passage.\n\n\"Did I vote with the extremist white Christian nationalist who called a motion to vacate the speakership or did I vote to save the extremist homophobic Christian nationalist speaker to keep him in office?\" Pocan said. \"Neither. I voted 'present' on this sideshow.\"", "source": {"uri": "salon.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Salon.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118136748", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:20:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:20:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:18:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://cbs6albany.com/news/nation-world/rep-marjorie-taylor-greene-triggers-legislation-to-remove-speaker-johnson-from-office-far-right-republicans-conference-spending-government-shutdown-motion-to-vacate-paul-gosar-thomas-massie-ukraine-israel-kevin-mccarthy", "title": "Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene triggers legislation to remove Speaker Johnson from office", "body": "WASHINGTON (TND) -- The House of Representatives swiftly voted down far-right Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's effort to remove Speaker of the House Mike Johnson from the speakership, voting 359-43 to table the ouster motion.\n\nOverwhelming majorities of both Republicans and Democrats voted to permanently delay the motion, with 196 Republicans and 163 Democrats voting to prevent a return to the abject chaos the House saw in October after former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy was removed from the podium, becoming the first House leader in U.S. history to be forcibly removed from the top job.\n\nGreene triggered the vote Wednesday afternoon, attempting to bring about the next step in a parliamentary procedure she began weeks ago.\n\nShe filed a motion to vacate the chair against Johnson, who was elected Speaker in late October following McCarthy's ouster by the same procedure, in late March after the House successfully passed a $1.2 trillion spending package to avert a government shutdown. In echoes of Rep. Matt Gaetz's, R-Fla., professed rationale for ousting McCarthy, Greene said that Johnson had betrayed conservative principles and the House Republican Conference by agreeing to such a large spending bill and relying on Democratic votes to pass the legislation.\n\n\"No Republican in good conscience can vote for the uniparty minibus. This is not a Republican bill,\" she wrote in a post on X, formerly Twitter. \"It is a Chuck Schumer, Democrat-controlled bill coming from the \"Republican-controlled\" House. The Speaker of the House should not bring it to the floor.\"\n\nGreene gained support in the intervening weeks from a pair of fellow far-right House members, Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., and Paul Gosar, R-Ariz., after Johnson brought long-delayed foreign aid funding to support Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan to the House floor over the objection of many conservatives in his conference.\n\n\"Our border cannot be an afterthought. We need a Speaker who puts America first rather than bending to the reckless demands of the warmongers, neocons, and the military-industrial complex making billions from a costly and endless war half a world away,\" Gosar said in a statement to The Hill.\n\nGreene threatened to bring her ouster resolution to the floor last Wednesday but had been meeting with Johnson earlier this week in what were believed to be negotiations over her scrapping the motion to vacate.", "source": {"uri": "cbs6albany.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WRGB"}, "authors": [{"uri": Marjorie Taylor Greene triggers effort to remove House Speaker Mike Johnson from office", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene called Wednesday for a vote to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, pressing ahead with her long-shot effort despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels tired of the political chaos.\n\nGreene, who is one of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nThe vote, which under House rules is required within two days, could happen imminently.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package with funds for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nPeople are also reading... Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"I just have to do my job every day,\" Johnson said Monday.\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team has said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\nTrump also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago for a visit, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, R-Ga., a high-profile provocateur.\n\nNational Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene and Speaker Johnson search for offramp as vote on his ouster simmers By LISA MASCARO, KEVIN FREKING and STEPHEN GROVES - Associated Press\n\nForcing the vote could bring the House chamber to a standstill, as happened last year when eight Republicans voted to ousted Kevin McCarthy from the speaker's office, and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOr it could be over in a matter of minutes, as Democrats join Republicans to table the effort.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, and there is no immediate successor if Johnson is removed.\n\nThese 8 Republicans stood apart to remove Kevin McCarthy as House speaker Rep. {"uri": "8118184375", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:14:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:14:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:13:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.thetrentonline.com/us-house-of-representatives-rejects-bid-to-oust-speaker-mike-johnson/", "title": "US House of Representatives Rejects Bid to Oust Speaker Mike Johnson - The Trent", "body": "WASHINGTON DC, USA -- In a swift and decisive action, the US House of Representatives on Wednesday, May 8, 2024, evening rejected a resolution by Republican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene to remove Speaker Mike Johnson from his leadership post.\n\nThe motion to table Greene's resolution was overwhelmingly approved with bipartisan support, marking a significant victory for Johnson amidst internal party conflicts.\n\nThe final vote tallied at 359 to 43, with the majority of Democrats joining a substantial number of Republicans to thwart the ousting attempt.\n\nThis vote came as Johnson recently endeavoured to pass a major foreign aid package, which faced staunch opposition from hardline conservative members of his party.\n\nIn response to the potential leadership shake-up, House Democratic leadership had earlier communicated their intention to support Johnson.\n\n\"Democrats will help Johnson keep his job by voting to table,\" announced the Democratic leadership, aligning with Johnson to preserve stability in the House leadership.\n\nThe controversy began when Rep. Greene, after a series of meetings with Speaker Johnson and Republican Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky, decided to initiate a motion to vacate the chair.\n\nThis move caught many in the GOP leadership off guard, particularly after what they considered productive discussions that suggested more time before any drastic measures.\n\n\"I was shocked,\" said GOP Rep. Austin Scott of Georgia, reflecting the surprise within Republican ranks following Greene's sudden decision.\n\nThis event underscores the ongoing struggles within the Republican Party and the complex dynamics at play as they navigate leadership challenges and legislative priorities.\n\nThe House was on the brink of a weeklong recess when the motion was introduced, setting a rapid timetable for resolution.\n\nAs the situation continues to unfold, further updates and reactions from both sides of the aisle are expected as lawmakers assess the implications of this vote on future legislative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia while urging her and other House Republicans to hold off on removing Speaker Mike Johnson for the time being.\n\nOn Wednesday, Greene's motion to oust the speaker failed in a landslide vote of 359-43, with just 11 Republicans supporting the plan.\n\nA whopping 163 Democrats voted to save Johnson, which lends credence to MTG's scathing criticism that he's a puppet of the left. As a reminder, House Democrats vowed last month to block any GOP efforts to remove the Louisiana Republican from the speaker's chair.\n\nHours after the motion failed on Wednesday, Trump urged House Republicans to halt further attempts to boot Johnson, saying the intraparty disunity could weaken the GOP in this fall's elections.\n\nDespite opposing Johnson's ejection, the former president extolled Greene, who led the efforts to boot the incumbent speaker.\n\n\"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform. \"She's got Spirit, she's got Fight, and I believe she'll be around, and on our side, for a long time to come.\n\n\"However, right now, Republicans have to be fighting the Radical Left Democrats, and all the Damage they have done to our Country. With a Majority of One, shortly growing to three or four, we're not in a position of voting on a Motion to Vacate. At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time.\"\n\nThe presumptive GOP presidential nominee said he's doing well in the polls but internal conflicts could hurt him and other Republicans in November.\n\n\"We are leading in the Presidential Polls by a lot, both Nationally and in the Swing States,\" he wrote.\n\n\"Likewise, we are doing well in the Senate, and I believe will do well in the House. But if we show DISUNITY, which will be portrayed as CHAOS, it will negatively affect everything!\"\n\nTrump also complimented the speaker and expressed optimism for the future, as long as Republicans stand together.\n\n\"Mike Johnson is a good man who is trying very hard,\" he wrote. \"I also wish certain things were done over the last period of two months, but we will get them done, together.\n\n\"It is my request that Republicans vote for 'THE MOTION TO TABLE.' We WILL WIN BIG - AND IT WILL BE SOON!\"\n\nThe 10 Republicans who voted with Greene to advance the motion to remove Johnson were:\n\n* Andy Biggs of Arizona\n\n* Eric Burlison of Missouri\n\n* Eli Crane of Arizona\n\n* Warren Davidson of Ohio\n\n* Paul Gosar of Arizona\n\n* Thomas Massie of Kentucky\n\n* Alex Mooney of West Virginia\n\n* Barry Moore of Alabama\n\n* Chip Roy of Texas\n\n* Victoria Spartz of Indiana\n\nGreene and other conservatives have been at odds with Johnson over his support of American taxpayers funding endless foreign wars, especially in Ukraine.\n\nLast month, Johnson spearheaded a $95 billion foreign policy bill that authorizes an additional $61 billion in aid to Ukraine and an additional $26 billion for Israel.\n\nThe bloated foreign aid package passed with Democrats' support.\n\nOn Thursday morning, Massie lamented the United States' self-destructive deficit spending.\n\n\"America is on a path that won't end well,\" he wrote on the social media platform X.\n\n\"We are borrowing money at an unsustainable rate, accumulating enemies through endless war, and eroding rights like free speech & privacy. A Uniparty controls it.\"\n\nWhile Congress is sending billions of U.S. tax dollars to foreign nations, Americans are struggling to pay exorbitant grocery bills as their cities are ravaged by crime {"uri": "8119774197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:49:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:49:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:48:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://nationalnewswatch.com/2024/05/09/failure-to-oust-speaker-maga-mike-johnson-shows-strength-and-weakness-of-his-alliance-with-trump", "title": "Failure to oust Speaker 'MAGA Mike' Johnson shows strength and...", "body": "But the oversized role Trump played in propping up Johnson cannot be understated -- or relied upon to save the speaker again.\n\nIn fact, the indicted former president who has been known to flip his friends into foes warned that while Republicans shouldn't be voting to remove Johnson, \"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time.\"\n\nThe outcome puts on display the fragility of the unexpected but strategically beneficial alliance that Trump and Johnson have formed ahead of the November election when both hope to be returned to power -- the Republican president in the White House and the loyal foot soldier in Congress.\n\n\"Seems like they're on the same page, and I think that's great,\" said lawyer Cleta Mitchell, who was a key figure in Trump's efforts to challenge the 2020 election.\n\nJohnson has worked diligently to align himself with the former president, the conservative Christian setting aside his once critical views of the presidential contender to present himself as a chief implementer of the Trump Republican Party's Make America Great Again agenda on Capitol Hill.\n\nBarely six months on the job, since Johnson replaced the ousted then-Speaker Kevin McCarthy, the new leader has dashed multiple times to Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort, securing crucial support, including at a glitzy Republican National Committee gala this past weekend.\n\nWhen Trump invited Johnson to the stage to say a few words, the speaker praised the former president as the \"strongman\" the country needs in the White House. Trump and Johnson are cordial, according to a person with knowledge of their relationship, and granted anonymity to discuss it.\n\n\"He's doing a great job,\" Trump said alongside Johnson after another visit last month, ahead of the House vote to approve a national security package with Ukraine funding that Greene warned would lead to a vote on Johnson's ouster.\n\nIn return for his seal of approval, Trump is increasingly able to rely on the speaker's high-profile standing to legitimize his relentless attacks on the U.S. election process, the judicial system and the multiple criminal cases against him, including the federal indictment for his efforts to overturn the 2020 election ahead of the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol attack.\n\n\"All these cases need to be dropped,\" says Johnson, a constitutional lawyer, who as the House speaker is second in the line of presidential succession. \"President Trump has done nothing wrong. ... It has to stop.\"\n\nTrump is already pre-emptively contesting the 2024 election as potentially rigged before the first ballots are cast, and Johnson, who helped lead legal challenges to Joe Biden's 2020 election victory, is in a powerful position to again question the legitimacy of the outcome.\n\nAsked this week if he believed the 2020 election was legitimate and if he would stand by the new state-certified results this fall, Johnson shook his head in frustration, and demurred. \"What we're talking about today is the 2024 election, nobody can go back and relitigate what happened in 2020,\" he said.\n\nThe joint venture between Trump and Johnson was in clear focus Wednesday ahead of the House action when the speaker, flanked on the Capitol steps by a who's who of the former president's advisers, announced new legislation that would require proof of citizenship before Americans are eligible to vote.\n\nJohnson had promised Trump a voting-citizenship bill during one of the Mar-a-Lago visits, and the unveiling of it alongside Stephen Miller, the architect of Trump's hardline immigration policies, and others showed just how embedded the former president's Make America Great Again movement has become in the House speaker's agenda.\n\nElection experts said there is scant evidence that non-citizens vote in U.S. elections, and past reviews including one pursued by the Trump administration have not produced significant cases of wrongdoing.\n\nNevertheless, Johnson and the others argued without proof that immigrants are being brought into the U.S. to illegally vote. The legislation can be seen as groundwork for the challenges Trump may pose in the aftermath of the November election.\n\n\"If this bill does not become law, then Joe Biden and Democrats will have engineered one of the greatest interferences in any democratic nation in the history of the world,\" Miller said outside the Capitol.\n\nStill, the legislative push did not placate Greene, who hours later tried and failed to remove the speaker from office.\n\nColleagues booed in protest. An overwhelming majority, 359-43, kept Johnson in his job, for now.\n\n\"I'm proud of what I did today,\" Greene said afterward on the Capitol steps.\n\nIt's the second time in a matter of months that Republicans have worked to oust their own speaker, an unheard of level of party upheaval with a move rarely seen in U.S. history.\n\nWithout Democratic help, Johnson would have certainly faced a more dismal outcome. All told, 196 and 163 Democrats voted to table Greene's motion. But 11 Republicans voted to proceed with the effort, more than it took to remove McCarthy last fall, a first in U.S. history.\n\nDemocrats have also made clear their help was for this moment alone, and not a promise of an enduring partnership for Johnson's survival.\n\n\"Our decision to stop Marjorie Taylor Greene from plunging the country into further chaos is rooted in our commitment to solve problems,\" said Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., after the vote.\n\n\"The only thing we ask of our House Republican colleagues is for traditional Republicans to further isolate the extreme MAGA Republican wing of the GOP,\" said Jeffries, who is in line to become speaker if Democrats win control of the House in the fall. \"We need more common sense and less chaos.\"\n\nAsked about a future motion to vacate the speaker, Jeffries said, \"Haven't given it a thought.\"\n\nBy relying on Democratic backing, Johnson risks inciting more criticism that he is insufficiently loyal to the party.\n\nAnd the threat still lingers -- any single lawmaker can call up the motion to vacate the speaker.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Kevin Freking, Michelle Price, Stephen Groves, Mary Clare Jalonick and Farnoush Amiri contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "nationalnewswatch.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "National Newswatch"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Here's who supported it.", "body": "Efforts to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., failed Wednesday as a motion to vacate the chair was tabled by the chamber, defeating the effort to boot the Speaker in a decisive and bipartisan manner.\n\nThe motion was introduced by far-right Georgia Republican Marjorie Taylor Greene at 5:30 p.m. local time and a vote to table the motion, called by Majority Leader Steve Scalise, R-La., won 359-43 just 15 minutes after the motion was introduced.\n\n\"In this moment this country desperately needs a functioning Congress,\" Johnson said to reporters after the vote. \"That's what an overwhelming majority of the Republican members of this body chose today.\"\n\nWhile introducing the motion, the culmination of an over month-long threat from Greene, the representative was heckled and called opponents of the bill \"the uni-party.\"\n\nThe attempt to oust the speaker lacked support from face of the Republican party and its presumptive 2024 presidential candidate Donald Trump.\" If we show DISUNITY, which will be portrayed as CHAOS, it will negatively affect everything! Mike Johnson is a good man who is trying very hard,\" Trump said on Truth Social.\n\nThe final tally showed 32 Democrats and 11 Republicans voted against tabling the motion; seven members, all Democrats, voted present and 21 members did not vote.\n\nDemocrats who moved to advance Greene's motion, cited reservations about saving the speaker over his key role in efforts to overturn the 2020 election. Democratic lawmakers also took aim at Johnson's conservative credentials such as his anti-abortion views.\n\nHere's who voted against tabling the motion to vacate against Speaker of the House Mike {"uri": "8118075625", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:17:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:17:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:17:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2024/05/marjorie-taylor-greene-mike-johnson-speaker-ukraine.html", "title": "Marjorie Taylor Greene Would Like to Fade Into the Bushes Now", "body": "This was supposed to be the week in which Georgia Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene had pledged to hold a snap vote on Speaker Mike Johnson's leadership, the culmination of a threat months in the making. She wouldn't have succeeded in ousting him, after Democrats had announced they'd provide the votes to save Johnson. But, at least in her head, she would have made some sort of point.\n\nBut Greene and her army of two other people have backed off for now, having secured a few hours of chit-chat time with Johnson as an acceptable alternative to a botched execution. Following her second meeting with Johnson in as many days on Tuesday, Greene told reporters that \"the ball is in Mike Johnson's court\" to act on her several \"suggestions\" she proposed to him. She offered no timeline on when she expected a response.\n\n\"That's up to Mike Johnson, and it can't drag out,\" she said. \"These are things that need to be done.\"\n\nThese meetings were called at Greene's request, and if Johnson is feeling any distress, he's not displaying it publicly. He called their conversations \"productive,\" downplaying them as run-of-the-mill talks he'd have with members at any time. \"I heard Marjorie and Thomas [Massie]'s ideas, just like I have every day for the last six months heard others.\" To the extent he was firm with them, though, he said this: \"It's not a negotiation.\"\n\nIndeed, the only one really dragging things out is Greene, not Johnson.\n\nAfter Johnson passed a government-funding bill disliked by Greene (and plenty of other conservatives, albeit those with more limited delusions of grandeur) in March, she warned him that his speakership was on the line. This was effectively a warning to not put Ukraine funding up for a vote next. Johnson did it anyway.\n\nBut the cavalry never arrived for Greene when Congress returned from recess last week. While plenty of conservatives were irate at Johnson for passing bipartisan bills on government funding, surveillance, and Ukraine, their prevailing impulse -- with most meaningful legislative work done for the year -- was just to get through November and hash out their leadership drama afterward. The party's presidential nominee, meanwhile, had no appetite for another House Republican meltdown to embarrass the party while his name is on the ballot. Greene misunderstood both how exhausted her fellow Republicans were with these shenanigans, and how quickly \"governing\" season had pivoted to campaign season following the Ukraine vote. The previous 18 months were for beating up on one another. The next six months are for beating up on leftist extravagances.\n\nSince Greene announced that she would force the vote on Johnson's speakership this week, she has spent most of her time looking for a way to back out, and to stay in Trump's good graces, while saving face. And so she brought to her meeting with Johnson a quartet of demands for the speaker: no more money for Ukraine; defunding special counsel Jack Smith's investigation into Donald Trump; only putting bills up for a vote if they have support of a majority of the majority (the unfortunately named \"Hastert rule\"); and a promise to enact \"a 1 percent across-the-board spending cut as part of stopgap funding legislation if the 12 annual appropriations bills aren't enacted by the Sept. 30 deadline .\"\n\nTo just get through 2024, Johnson could agree to the Ukraine and \"Hastert rule\" provisions without any real consequences. Ukraine assistance is done for the year, and there aren't significant, must-pass bills with limited Republican support on the horizon. The other two provisions -- on \"defunding\" Jack Smith and enacting a blanket spending cut -- have zero Democratic support and, if insisted upon at the next government funding deadline, could cause government shutdowns, for which Republicans would be blamed, a month before the election.\n\nThat said, rather than giving an inch, there's good reason for Johnson to just stand firm here and dare Greene to do something about it. Even if he were able to give her some things here, some things there, giving her anything would reinforce an awful, recurring trend of the 118 Congress that needs to end: that any couple of members can blackmail the speaker into sending the party down a new, risky, and ultimately self-defeating strategic course. And there's no better time for Johnson to end it than during this brief window when Democrats are willing to bail him out.\n\nThe only question for Greene now is how she chooses to claim victory in defeat. She could take some words that Johnson says in a press conference and insist that those words were a hard-fought concession. She could turn her attention to an entirely new matter and wait for people to forget how she caved. She could still force the vote on Johnson's speakership, lose, fall out of favor with Trump for a few months, and then work her way back up. Or she could just say, \"The numbers weren't there; we'll get him in the next Congress,\" get made fun of for a few days, and move on with her life.", "source": {"uri": "slate.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8118116081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:59:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:59:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:58:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/speaker-mike-johnson-oust-motion-to-vacate-marjorie-taylor-greene/article_f807de84-5d10-5342-af6e-d35affcc1e13.html", "title": "Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene triggers effort to remove House Speaker Mike Johnson from office", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Hardline Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene called Wednesday for a vote to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, pressing ahead with her long-shot effort despite pushback from Republicans at the highest levels tired of the political chaos.\n\nGreene, who is one of Donald Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, stood on the House floor and read a long list of \"transgressions\" she said Johnson had committed as speaker. Colleagues booed in protest.\n\nThe vote, which under House rules is required within two days, could happen imminently.\n\nThe Georgia Republican had vowed she would force a vote on the motion to vacate the Republican speaker if he dared to advance a foreign aid package with funds for Ukraine, which was overwhelmingly approved late last month and signed into law.\n\nPeople are also reading... Nebraska volleyball's Harper Murray accused of shoplifting from Scheels Another mall retailer will close Lincoln store after bankruptcy filing 'Out of my control': John Cook gives update on Harper Murray's status with team New DMV center in Lincoln to open this month Nebraska store manager allegedly scratched winning lottery ticket and then bought it Two women dead after rural Lancaster County crash last week, officials say South Lincoln church fire causes over $1M in damages, officials say Nebraska football scholarship lineman enters transfer portal Lincoln man's 2023 death ruled a homicide; wife arrested Lincoln Journal Star 2024 Primary Election Voter Guide: Local candidates on the issues Bill Murray makes lasting impression while in Omaha for Berkshire Hathaway meeting Tape measure homer puts Nebraska baseball in tie atop Big Ten standings Wahoo police looking into allegations of sex assaults by Bishop Neumann High School students Nebraska volleyball gets commitment from middle blocker Manaia Ogbechie Post-spring progress and projected depth chart for Nebraska running backs\n\nBut in recent days it seemed her effort had cooled, as she and Johnson met repeatedly for a potential resolution.\n\nJohnson of Louisiana marched on, saying he had been willing to take the risk, believing it was important for the U.S. to back Ukraine against Russia's invasion and explaining he wanted to be on the \"right side of history.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"I just have to do my job every day,\" Johnson said Monday.\n\nIn a highly unusual move, the speaker received a boost from Democrats led by Rep. Hakeem Jeffries of New York, whose leadership team has said it was time to \"turn the page\" on the GOP turmoil and vote to table Greene's resolution -- almost ensuring Johnson's job is saved, for now.\n\nTrump also weighed in after Johnson trekked to Mar-a-Lago for a visit, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee giving the speaker his nod of approval. And Trump's hand-picked leader at the Republican National Committee urged House Republicans off the move.\n\nThe move now poses its own political risks for Greene, R-Ga., a high-profile provocateur.\n\nNational Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene and Speaker Johnson search for offramp as vote on his ouster simmers By LISA MASCARO, KEVIN FREKING and STEPHEN GROVES - Associated Press\n\nForcing the vote could bring the House chamber to a standstill, as happened last year when eight Republicans voted to ousted Kevin McCarthy from the speaker's office, and Democrats declined to help save him.\n\nOr it could be over in a matter of minutes, as Democrats join Republicans to table the effort.\n\nOusting McCarthy resulted in a nearly monthlong search for a new GOP leader, and there is no immediate successor if Johnson is removed.\n\nThese 8 Republicans stood apart to remove Kevin McCarthy as House speaker Rep. {"uri": "8118217976", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:57:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:57:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:56:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://redstate.com/jenniferoo/2024/05/08/house-speaker-mike-johnson-was-spared-ouster-because-in-2024-a-stalled-congress-hurts-both-parties-n2173945", "title": "Speaker Mike Johnson Spared Ouster Because a Stalled Congress Hurts Both Parties", "body": "The opinions expressed by contributors are their own and do not necessarily represent the views of RedState.com.\n\nAs our editor Becca Lower reported, the House of Representatives effectively silenced GA Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene in her motion to vacate House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) from leadership.\n\nThe House voted 359-43, with 11 Republicans voting against, and seven Democrats choosing to vote present. This came after Monday and Tuesday meetings between Greene and Speaker Johnson to have a meeting of the minds on the issues Greene was having with the Speaker. The fact that this vacate vote was brought on Wednesday could well be a result of those meetings.\n\nGreene is not well-liked amongst her colleagues, and beyond Arizona Rep. Paul Gosar and her partner in this quixotic quest, Kentucky Rep. Thomas Massie, Greene was not moving the needle in rallying more Republicans to her cause.\n\nRather than having the motion withdrawn, it might have looked better for Greene to appear resolute, knowing full well that the vote would fail. The normally loquacious and camera-loving Greene has been radio silent since the vote was done. And \"Sassy with Massie\" also didn't go very far.\n\nMassie took to X to lament the power of the Uniparty in keeping Speaker Johnson firmly in place.\n\nIt's not a new paradigm.\n\nSay what you will about Pelosi and the Democrat faction, they aren't stupid -- they know how to play the long game. They also understand that a speakership food fight would destroy any electoral goodwill they might have (which is smaller than they think), and distract from their agendas of abortion, mutilation, destroying norms, and destroying Trump, and not necessarily in that order.\n\nAs reported in April, California Rep. Ro Khanna had already stated he would vote to table any motion to vacate, and both South Carolina Rep. Jim Clyburn and New York Rep. and Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries alluded to the fact that they would be inclined to do the same. So, why Massie is surprised at this shows that he either had his own agenda, or he simply does not have a clue about the pulse of his own chamber.\n\nPerhaps a bit of both.\n\nJohnson's favorability has also been on the rise over the past few weeks. Soon after the egregious Ukraine aid vote that had Greene's and Massie's hackles up, Johnson exhibited real leadership in addressing the college campus protests erupting across the country and calling for the president of Columbia University to quell the unrest or resign.\n\nIn terms of Republicans and their inclinations, my colleague Duke wrote:\n\nWe only have 182 days until the November election.\n\nThe GOP majority in the House of Representatives is razor-thin.\n\nDuke echoes the sentiments of many Americans, who simply want the House to get down to the business in front of their faces, and the majority of the House agreed. {"uri": "2024-05-349556380", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:27:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:27:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:56:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.wdhn.com/hill-politics/house-blocks-greenes-resolution-to-oust-johnson/", "title": "House blocks Greene's resolution to oust Johnson", "body": "The House on Wednesday overwhelmingly voted to protect Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) from a conservative coup, torpedoing an effort by Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) to oust the GOP leader from the top job.\n\nThe chamber voted 359-43-7 on a motion to table Greene's motion to vacate, preventing the removal resolution from hitting the floor for a vote.\n\nThe final vote -- which was widely expected amid bipartisan opposition to the ouster gambit -- deals a major blow to Greene, who filed her measure more than a month ago and had threatened to trigger it ever since.\n\nIt means Johnson, who won the gavel in October following the ouster of former Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.), will remain in the top job. But the vote puts him in the precarious position of being a GOP Speaker propped up by Democrats, which could earn him the ire of conservatives.\n\nIn brief remarks delivered shortly after Wednesday's vote, Johnson thanked his colleagues for their support.\n\n\"I appreciate the show of confidence from my colleagues to defeat this misguided effort,\" he said. \"That is certainly what it was.\"\n\n\"As I've said from the beginning and I've made clear every day, I intend to do my job. I intend to do what I believe to be the right thing, which is what I was elected to do, and I'll let the chips fall where they may,\" he continued. \"In my view, that is leadership.\"\n\nGreene filed her motion to vacate Wednesday afternoon, a surprise to some after it appeared that the Georgia Republican was backing off her threat. {"uri": "2024-05-349594697", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:42:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:42:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:15:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.counton2.com/news/south-carolina-news/house-kills-greenes-resolution-to-oust-speaker-johnson-how-did-south-carolinas-delegation-vote/", "title": "House kills Greene's resolution to oust Speaker Johnson. How did South Carolina's delegation vote?", "body": "WASHINGTON (WCBD)- The U.S. House on Wednesday overwhelmingly rejected an effort by conservative Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) to oust Rep. Mike Johnson (R-La.) from the Speakership.\n\nThe chamber voted 359-43 to table, or kill, Greene's motion to vacate, with seven Democrats voting present. Just 10 Republicans sided with Greene to vote against it.\n\n\"I appreciate the show of confidence from my colleagues to defeat this misguided effort,\" Johnson said after the vote. \"Hopefully this is the end of the personality politics and the frivolous character assassination that has defined the 118th Congress.\"\n\nAll seven South Carolina delegation members voted to block Greene's effort.\n\nShortly after the vote, Rep. Russell Fry (R-S.C.) called Greene's effort \"the wrong move at the wrong time.\"\n\n\"Today I voted to table the resolution to declare of [sic] of the Speaker vacant,\" Fry wrote on X, formerly Twitter. \"You don't kick a coach out in the middle of a game. Let's unite as a party and as a conference and focus on the real priorities of the American people.\"\n\nRep. Jeff Duncan (R-S.C.) also invoked a sports metaphor in explaining his decision not to oust the Speaker despite having \"differences in policy, strategy, and tactics\" with him.\n\n\"Just as you don't fire the coach in the middle of the game in football or basketball, we shouldn't fire the Speaker in the middle of a session where we need to pass vital legislation for Americans,\" Duncan wrote on X. \"President Trump and countless Republicans agree that we should not oust Speaker Johnson. Let me be clear, Speaker Johnson was nominated by the Republican Conference for this role, and I have always stood with any nominee from the Conference.\"\n\nRep. Nancy Mace (R-S.C.), one of eight GOP members who voted to oust former Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) last year, posted a simple \"thumbs up\" emoji after the vote. She previously told Newsmax she didn't know why Greene was bringing the motion because she was \"going to lose.\"\n\nThe final vote -- which was widely expected amid bipartisan opposition to the ouster gambit -- deals a major blow to Greene, who filed her measure more than a month ago and had threatened to trigger it ever since.\n\nIt means Johnson, who won the gavel in October, will remain in the top job. But the vote puts him in the precarious position of being a GOP Speaker propped up by Democrats, which could earn him the ire of conservatives.", "source": {"uri": "counton2.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8118143972", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:29:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:29:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:27:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/marjorie-taylor-greene-files-motion-212643875.html", "title": "Marjorie Taylor Greene's very public bid to oust Mike Johnson fails minutes after she files motion", "body": "The House voted 359-43 to table the Republican congresswoman's ouster attempt, allowing Mr Johnson to stay in his position.\n\nMs Greene introduced her motion around 5pm after publicly vowing to do so for days. She met with the speaker twice this week alongside one of her few allies, GOP Representative Thomas Massie.\n\nThe motion was privileged which meant the House would have been forced to vote within 48 hours. However, the vote commenced minutes after Ms Greene finished speaking.\n\nDemocrats and some GOP members had vowed earlier this week to save Mr Johnson, making Wednesday's outcome unsurprising. In the end, 11 GOP lawmakers joined Democrats in doing so.\n\nGOP members lambasted Ms Greene's motion moments after she announced it.\n\n\"It's a gimmick, it's a joke, it's laughable,\" Republican Representative Max Miller told reporters. \"We have real work to do.\"\n\n\"It's going to sow discord...and by the way, it's going to fail,\" GOP Congressman Dusty Johnson said outside the House chambers.\n\nMs Greene criticised Mr Johnson for working with Democrats to pass a series of foreign aid bills which allocated funds to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan.\n\nMs Greene had told The Independent on Tuesday that the speaker has been \"working with Democrats the entire time.\"\n\n\"[The Democrats] are ready to deliver the votes to save his speakership, because they support him because of what he's delivered for the Democrats and the Biden agenda,\" she said.\n\nIn their meetings earlier this week, Ms Greene and Mr Massie gave Mr Johnson a list of demands. The pair asked Mr Johnson to block future aid to Ukraine, as well as defund Special Counsel Jack Smith's probes into former president Donald Trump. Mr Smith is investigating the classified documents case and the 6 January riots.\n\nThese asks were largely symbolic because the Senate and President Joe Biden would likely have blocked them.\n\nThe other side levelled similar criticisms on Tuesday while it was still unclear when Ms Greene would bring her motion. Democratic Representative Eric Swalwell of California criticised Greene for seeming wobbly on pushing Mr Johnson out.\n\n\"I can just speak for our side -- we're gonna be the side that wants to get s**t done, we'll be united, we'll deliver the votes,\" he told The Independent. \"And as I said, it looks more like a motion to vacillate than a motion to vacate because she can't decide what she wants to do other than try and be famous.\"\n\nMr Johnson, a GOP representative from Louisiana, became speaker in October 2023. He won the leadership position after 22 days of turmoil in the House of Representatives following the removal of former speaker Kevin McCarthy.\n\nLast week, Ms Greene vowed to bring the motion to vacate against the speaker. At a press conference, Ms Greene and Mr Massie blasted work between Mr Johnson and Mr Jeffries as a culmination of the \"uniparty.\"\n\n\"The uniparty is 'Make Ukraine Great Again,'\" Ms Greene said on 1 May. \"The uniparty is about funding every single foreign war. Thomas Massie of Kentucky said in a statement to Blaze News.\n\nRepublican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia sought to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson from the speakership on Wednesday, but the move was soundly rejected, with most House Democrats joining with most House Republicans to put the kibosh on the ouster effort.\n\n\"The Uniparty has spoken, and Mike Johnson is their speaker,\" GOP Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky said in a statement to Blaze News.\n\nOverall, the vote was 359-43 in favor of tabling the motion to vacate, with seven voting present. While 196 Republicans and 163 Democrats joined together in the vote to table the matter, 11 Republicans and 32 Democrats opposed the motion to table.\n\n\"It's a new paradigm in Congress.\"\n\nThe 11 Republicans who opposed tabling the motion included Reps. Greene, Massie, Warren Davidson of Ohio, Alex Mooney of West Virginia, Barry Moore of Alabama; Victoria Spartz of Indiana. Chip Roy of Texas; Paul Gosar of Arizona, Eli Crane of Arizona, Eric Burlison of Missouri, and Andy Biggs of Arizona.\n\n\"It's a new paradigm in Congress. Nancy Pelosi, and most republicans voted to keep Uniparty Speaker Mike Johnson. These are the eleven, including myself, who voted NOT to save him,\" Massie tweeted.\n\nLast week, House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York, Democratic Whip Katherine Clark of Massachusetts, and Democratic Caucus Chair Pete Aguilar of California had announced that if Greene sought to oust the speaker, they would vote to table the motion to vacate.\n\n\"Whereas, Speaker {"uri": "8118150081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:36:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:36:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:34:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/republican-firebrand-forces-vote-on-ousting-us-house-speaker/article_2c44cba8-91e3-56d9-8f82-7da6b93c0957.html", "title": "Republican firebrand forces vote on ousting US House speaker", "body": "A right-wing rebel lawmaker moved Wednesday to topple the Republican leader of the US House of Representatives in a vote that will likely fail -- but could mire the already-divided party in fresh conflict ahead of November's elections.\n\nUnder House rules, any single lawmaker can force a vote to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, and Georgia conservative Marjorie Taylor Greene finally pulled the trigger, more than six weeks after filing a \"motion to vacate\" his spot atop the Republican majority.\n\nBut Greene's effort has failed to gain traction among her colleagues and, crucially, is not supported by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, who recently said the speaker was \"doing a very good job.\"\n\nGreene is even opposed by Democratic leaders, ensuring the effort is almost certain to fall flat when it comes to the floor. House rules require a vote within 48 hours, although the leadership could move to dismiss the resolution within hours.\n\nGreene, a Trump ally, has two public supporters but none of the broader backing on the right that prompted the removal last year of Johnson's predecessor, Kevin McCarthy.\n\nShe is vowing to plow ahead anyway, as she seeks to make Republicans go on the record about whether they support Johnson.\n\nMany right-wing lawmakers are upset with the speaker for relying on Democratic votes to pursue an agenda they see as a betrayal of their conservative outlook on issues from Ukraine aid to government funding.\n\n\"No Republican speaker should ever share power with the Democrats. American voters gave Republicans in the House the majority for a reason... Mike Johnson must resign or be removed,\" Greene posted on X on Friday.\n\nMore from this section NY: ACE Awards 2024 - Arrivals - 53059652 Trump's Courtroom Antics Lead to Judicial Caution 'We've lost a few fishermen': P.E.I. crews reminded life-jackets could prevent tragedy\n\nBut rank-and-file lawmakers are wary of repeating the chaos of McCarthy's removal in a right-wing rebellion that left the House paralyzed for three weeks as they struggled to find a replacement, before finally settling on Johnson.\n\nAnd with the presidential and congressional elections less than six months away, Republicans see threatening Johnson's gavel as divisive and damaging to their prospects of unified control in Washington.\n\nThe voting tally is sure to be scrutinized for what it suggests about Johnson's viability as a Republican leader after November.\n\nSome allies of the speaker fear that his rescue by Democrats could make his position untenable in the long term, although the scale of the pushback against Greene may have stilled their nerves.\n\n\"She's pretty much operating on her own, with one or two others who have expressed support for what she's doing,\" Bob Good, chairman of the hard-right House Freedom Caucus, told cable network NewsNation on Sunday.\n\nJohnson condemned the move in an interview on SiriusXM's \"The Laura Coates Show\" on Friday.\n\n\"I think it's wrong for the Republican Party, I think it's wrong for the institution, I think it's wrong for the country,\" he said.\n\nft/sst/dw", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) to oust Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) late Wednesday afternoon.\n\n\"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene. She's got Spirit, she's got Fight, and I believe she'll be around, and on our side, for a long time to come,\" Trump said in a Truth Social post on Wednesday, adding, \"However, right now, Republicans have to be fighting the Radical Left Democrats, and all the Damage they have done to our Country.\"\n\nIn a bipartisan vote of 359-43-7, the motion by Greene to have Johnson vacate his seat was tabled. Only 11 Republicans voted in favor of advancing the motion to oust Johnson, while a majority of Democrats joined in thwarting his removal.\n\nTrump shared that the timing was not right for advancing this motion.\n\n\"With a Majority of One, shortly growing to three or four, we're not in a position of voting on a Motion to Vacate. At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time,\" he said.\n\nGreene's effort to remove Johnson was in reaction to Republicans' frustration with Johnson's push for billions of dollars in Ukraine funding as part of the massive national security spending package. Many Republicans expressed concern that international priorities were being given more attention than the United States's own national security priorities along the southern border.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\n\"Mike Johnson is publicly saying funding Ukraine is now his top priority when less than 7 months ago he was against it,\" Greene wrote in a letter in April. \"The American people disagree -- they believe our border is the only border worth fighting a war over, and I agree with them.\"\n\nThe former president warned that a speaker ousting would create the perception of \"chaos\" in the Republican Party and affect election efforts later this year.\n\n\"We are leading in the Presidential Polls by a lot, both Nationally and in the Swing States. Likewise, we are doing well in the Senate, and I believe will do well in the House. But if we show DISUNITY, which will be portrayed as CHAOS, it will negatively affect everything!\" Trump said.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\nTrump called Johnson \"a good man who is trying very hard.\"\n\n\"I also wish certain things were done over the last period of two months, but we will get them done, together. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) (Olivier Douliery/AFP/Getty Images)\n\nFormer President Donald Trump took a break from his criminal hush money trial to tell Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene to cool it.\n\nTrump posted on Truth Social Thursday afternoon a video statement calling on Greene (R-GA) to give up on her \"majority of one\" quest to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson.\n\n\"Republicans have to be fighting the radical left Democrats, lunatics, I call them, and all the damage they have done to our country,\" Trump said. \"With the majority of one, shortly growing to three or four, we hope, we're not in a position of voting on a motion to vacate.\n\n\"At some point, we may very well be, but this is not the time.\"\n\nTrump hedged his approbation for Greene's much-aligned effort to oust Johnson with a bland compliment directed at the Louisiana lawmaker.\n\n\"Mike Johnson is a good man, a very good man, he's trying very hard,\" Trump said. \"But I also wish certain things were done over the last period of two or three months.\"\n\nALSO READ: 'Lord of the Flies': Inside MTG's effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson\n\nTrump did not elucidate what action he wished Johnson had taken. And his tempered flattery of the House speaker stood in stark contrast to the praise Trump heaped on Greene.\n\n\"I absolutely love Marjorie Taylor Greene,\" Trump declared. \"She's got spirit, she's got Fight, she's got spunk and I believe she'll be around, and on our side, for a long time to come.\"\n\nTrump also wedged in a zinger directed at Democrats and the \"fake news media\" he blamed for
